<p>The Education and Justice Departments will send a letter Friday to every public-school district in the country notifying school administrators that discrimination against transgender students violates federal civil-rights law.</p>

<p>In the letter, which offers the most detailed federal guidance yet for educators on transgender students and their rights, the departments interpret anti-discrimination laws to apply when a parent or guardian tells school administrators about their child&rsquo;s gender identity.</p>

<p>From there, the departments outline how Title IX forbids discrimination on the basis of gender identity in a variety of school functions, including housing, athletics, and single-sex classrooms. Other activities, including graduation ceremonies and yearbooks, are also covered.</p>

<aside class="callout-placeholder" data-source="primary-categorization"></aside>

<p>The letter also strongly sides with transgender students on the issue of restrooms and locker rooms, which have become a flashpoint nationwide in debates about transgender rights. In the guidance letter, schools are told not to discriminate against students who choose to use restrooms that correspond to their gender identity.</p>

<p>While the letter itself does not carry legal force, it notifies teachers and administrators that discrimination against transgender students could bring sanctions, including the painful loss of federal funding.</p>

<p>Under the Obama administration, federal agencies have increasingly considered transgender discrimination to be a form of sex discrimination. The Education and Justice Departments <a href="https://www.buzzfeed.com/chrisgeidner/federal-officials-protect-transgender-student-against-discri?utm_term=.ihjao6eB6D#.pyN1LMxGMn">first explicitly stated</a> that Title IX covers transgender discrimination in 2013, although Friday&rsquo;s letter is the strongest effort yet to apply that interpretation nationwide.</p>

<p>The letter caps a historic week for federal protection of transgender rights. On Monday, the Justice Department <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/05/state-sponsored-discrimination-loretta-lynch-takes-on-north-carolinas-hb2/481986/">filed a lawsuit</a> against North Carolina targeting HB2, the state&rsquo;s controversial bill requiring&mdash;among other things&mdash;transgender individuals to use bathrooms that don&rsquo;t correspond to their gender identity. In an impassioned press conference, Attorney General Loretta Lynch described the statute as &ldquo;state-sponsored discrimination&rdquo; and implicitly compared it to Jim Crow laws.</p>

<p>&ldquo;You have been told that this law protects vulnerable populations from harm. That is just not the case,&rdquo; Lynch said. &ldquo;What this law does is inflict further indignity for a population that has already suffered far more than its far share. This law provides no benefit to society, and all it does is harm innocent Americans.&rdquo;</p>

<p>The U.S. Navy announced Thursday it had fired the commander of 10 U.S. sailors briefly detained by Iran in January after their ship entered Iranian territorial waters in the Persian Gulf.</p>

<p>The <em>Navy Times</em> <a href="http://www.navytimes.com/story/military/2016/05/12/iran-farsi-island-sailors-capture-firing-rasch-meyer/84225038/">has more</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Cmdr. Eric Rasch, who at the time of the Jan. 12 incident was the executive officer of the Coastal Riverine Squadron 3, was removed from his job by Capt. Gary Leigh, head of Coastal Riverine Group 1, for what a Navy Expeditionary Combat Command release said was &ldquo;a loss of confidence&rdquo; in his ability to remain in command.</p>

<p>&quot;Capt. Gary Leigh, commander, CRG-1, made this determination following his review of a preliminary investigation into the incident near Farsi Island in the Arabian Gulf, Jan. 12-13, involving 10 CRS-3 Sailors,&quot; the release said. &quot;Rasch was assigned as the executive officer of CRS-3 during this time-frame.&quot;</p>

<p>Cmdr. Gregory Meyer, who was commanding officer at the time of the incident, is currently with Coastal Riverine Group 1, and has been put on &ldquo;administrative hold,&rdquo; meaning the Navy will not transfer him out of the unit, while a high-level review of the Navy&rsquo;s investigation into the incident continues, said two officials familiar with internal deliberations.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Rasch is the first officer formally disciplined for the incident. Navy investigators <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2016/04/07/navy-investigation-into-how-u-s-sailors-were-detained-by-iran-reaches-top-admirals/">completed their investigation</a> into what went wrong in April and forwarded their report to top Navy officials. Its findings have not yet been made public.</p>

<p>The incident occurred on January 12, when the sailors were traveling in two small riverine craft from Bahrain to Kuwait through the Gulf. Along the way, they reportedly drifted into Iranian territorial waters, where two Iranian vessels intercepted them and detained the crew. No gunfire was exchanged.</p>

<p>A <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/01/sailors-released/423885/">frantic diplomatic effort</a> between U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry and his Iranian counterpart, Mohammed Javad Zarif, led to the release of the sailors and their boats the following morning.</p>

<p>The timing proved awkward for both countries, with President Obama scheduled to give his State of the Union address on the night of the incident and Iran only days away from receiving long-awaited sanctions relief as part of the nuclear accord it struck with six world powers.</p>

            <img
                src="http://cdn.thewire.com/media/img/mt/2016/05/AP_336765202724/lead_large.jpg"
                alt="Image "
                title="Five Questions About Donald Trump&#39;s Racist Butler"
            >
        
        
    


    
    

</figure>

<p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeeves">Jeeves</a> would be appalled by the lack of discretion.</p>

<p>Thursday was a pretty good day for Donald Trump&mdash;he swept into Washington for his meetings with Speaker Paul Ryan and other Republican leaders, and left town with a conciliatory statement from Ryan, a downright cordial one from Senator Lindsey Graham (who once compared nominating him to being shot), and <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/usa-election-hatch-idUSKCN0Y32KS">warm statements from others.</a></p>

<p>Yet some of the attention for those meetings is being stolen by a series of appallingly racist comments made on Facebook by Trump&rsquo;s longtime butler at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida, Anthony Senecal. Here&rsquo;s a sample, <a href="http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/05/trump-butler-anthony-senecal-facebook-kill-obama">caught by </a><em><a href="http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/05/trump-butler-anthony-senecal-facebook-kill-obama">Mother Jones</a> </em>(and apparently since deleted):</p>

<blockquote>
<p>To all my friends on FB, just a short note to you on our pus headed &quot;president&quot; !!!! This character who I refer to as zero (0) should have been taken out by our military and shot as an enemy agent in his first term !!!!! Instead he still remains in office doing every thing he can to gut the America we all know and love !!!!! Now comes Donald J Trump to put an end to the corruption in government !!!!</p>
</blockquote>

<p>In addition to calling for the military to stage a coup and execute Obama, he also called for lynching the president:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>I feel it is time for the SECOND AMERICAN REVOLUTION !!!!! The only way we will change this crooked government is to douche it !!!!! This might be the time with this kenyan fraud in power !!!!! ...[W]ith the last breath I draw I will help rid this America of the scum infested in its government--and if that means dragging that ball less dick head from the white mosque and hanging his scrawny ass from the portico--count me in !!!!!</p>
</blockquote>

<p><a href="http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/05/trump-butler-anthony-senecal-facebook-kill-obama">David Corn has some more examples</a>. Even if the posts have been deleted, Senecal didn&rsquo;t deny them. In fact, he expanded on them to NBC&rsquo;s Alex Jaffe:</p>

<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p dir="ltr" lang="en">In intvu w <a href="https://twitter.com/ajjaffe">@ajjaffe</a>, Trump&#39;s butler calls for Obama to be &quot;hung from the portico of the White Mosque,&quot; calls Obama daughters &quot;rent-a-kids&quot;</p>
&mdash; Beth Fouhy (@bfouhy) <a href="https://twitter.com/bfouhy/status/730845142786183170">May 12, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>

<p>(What does &ldquo;rent-a-kids&rdquo; even mean?)</p>

<p>Senecal&rsquo;s statements should inspire, in addition to a million &ldquo;Clue&rdquo; jokes, a few questions about Trump. The two men are close&mdash;a <em>New York Times </em>profile in March missed the racism but did capture the tightness of Senecal&rsquo;s relationship with the entertainer, for whom he&rsquo;s worked since 1985. (Senecal say he&rsquo;s been at Mar-a-Lago since about 1959.)</p>

<ol type="1">
	<li><strong>Who&rsquo;s lying about Anthony Senecal?</strong> Trump&rsquo;s campaign, in response to the revelation of Senecal&rsquo;s Facebook posts, disavowed them and said that he had not worked for Trump for years. But Senecal told both <em>Mother Jones </em>and the <em>Times</em>&mdash;whose reporter, Jason Horowitz, roamed the grounds at Mar-a-Lago with him&mdash;that he continued to work there. Senecal <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/16/us/politics/donald-trump-butler-mar-a-lago.html?_r=0">says</a> Trump specifically asked him to stay on staff as a historian-in-residence, even as he retired from butler duties. Someone&rsquo;s not telling the truth, and Trump&rsquo;s campaign is the more obvious culprit. Which brings up the next point:</li>
	<li><strong>What kind of populist has a butler?</strong> OK, this one actually isn&rsquo;t that tough a question. FDR was wealthy, too! For Trump, his wealth and implausible Horatio Alger self-image make him an aspirational figure for many supporters, rather than a symbol of elitist entitlement. Still, there&rsquo;s something rich (pardon the phrase) about the fact that, <a href="https://twitter.com/Olivianuzzi/status/730842581899333632">as Olivia Nuzzi put it</a>, &ldquo;Romney&#39;s car elevator made him unelectable in 2012 but Trump&#39;s psychotic racist butler is just another Thursday in 2016.&rdquo;</li>
	<li><strong>When exactly will Trump start hiring the best people? </strong>Trump&rsquo;s answer to many staffing questions is that he&rsquo;ll hire the best people. It&rsquo;s his answer to why his administration will work so much better than previous ones, and it&rsquo;s his answer to why voters needn&rsquo;t worry about his lack of experience in government, defense, foreign policy, economic policy, etc. When, precisely, does he expect to start doing that? The fact that Senecal has been such a longtime, trusted employee ought not to fill anyone with confidence. And his comments follow, for example, the saga over campaign manager Corey Lewandowski grabbing and manhandling a reporter, than lying about it despite video evidence.</li>
	<li><strong>Why did Trump manage to denounce Senecal so much faster than David Duke?</strong> Remember when former KKK leader David Duke voiced his support for Trump back in February, Trump initially played dumb. &ldquo;Well, just so you understand, I don&rsquo;t know anything about David Duke,&rdquo; he told Jake Tapper. &ldquo;OK? I don&rsquo;t know anything about what you&rsquo;re even talking about with white supremacy or white supremacists. So, I don&rsquo;t know.&rdquo; That was implausible&mdash;he&rsquo;d criticized Duke as far back as the 1990s&mdash;and he of course reversed himself eventually, blaming (again, implausibly) an earpiece problem. Now comes the case of Senecal, when Trump&rsquo;s campaign issued a statement quickly, saying, &ldquo;Tony Senecal has not worked at Mar-a-Lago for years, but nevertheless we totally and completely disavow the horrible statements made by him.&rdquo; Trump noted he had never met Duke; not so with Senecal. Perhaps the faster response is evidence that Trump really is changing his approach, and pivoting toward the general election. However ...</li>
	<li><strong>What&rsquo;s up with all the racists who support Trump&rsquo;s campaign? </strong>One needn&rsquo;t accuse Trump of bigotry&mdash;though there&rsquo;s ample evidence to do so&mdash;to be perturbed by the number of people with repellent views who are ardent Trump backers. Meanwhile, minority voters hold overwhelmingly unfavorable views of Trump, <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/05/the-way-donald-trump-speaks-toand-aboutminorities/481155/">for some reason</a>. Does this perturb the Trump campaign?</li>
</ol>

<p>Will any of this hurt Trump? Past experience says no&mdash;he seems to just keep rolling, though it&rsquo;s true that open white supremacy and calls for the president&rsquo;s death tend to turn off even the most forbearing ally. Trump has managed to shift expectations so far that the revelation of comments such as these seem like simply the latest in a parade of inanities (which they are), rather than a shocking shift away from normal (which they also are). All in all, it&rsquo;s an embarrassing situation for the Trump campaign. Senecal told the <em>Times </em>that Trump&rsquo;s mood could be reliably gauged by the color of his hat&mdash;red meaning ornery, white meaning pleasant. It&rsquo;s a good bet that Trump will be donning the red cap this evening.</p>

<p>The world&rsquo;s anti-doping authority has declared that Kenyan national athletics do not comply with international standards, putting the country&rsquo;s participation in the Rio Olympics this summer at risk.</p>

<p>The World Anti-Doping Agency announced the recommendation from its independent review committee Thursday afternoon on Twitter:</p>

<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p dir="ltr" lang="en">The <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/WADA?src=hash">#WADA</a> CRC has made the unanimous recommendation that <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Kenya?src=hash">#Kenya</a> be declared non-compliant with immediate effect.</p>
&mdash; WADA (@wada_ama) <a href="https://twitter.com/wada_ama/status/730791681503731712">May 12, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>

<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p dir="ltr" lang="en">The CRC cites issues with <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Kenya?src=hash">#Kenya</a>&#39;s legislation which it says is not in line with the World Anti-Doping Code.</p>
&mdash; WADA (@wada_ama) <a href="https://twitter.com/wada_ama/status/730791938702639106">May 12, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>

<p>The legislation WADA cites was approved last month. Facing pressure from WADA to crack down on cheating in sports, Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta signed an anti-doping bill that created a national agency that would fine and imprison athletes who are found to be guilty of doping, <a href="http://www.bbc.com/sport/athletics/36087174">according to the BBC</a>.</p>

<p>The committee&rsquo;s recommendation must be ratified by WADA&rsquo;s board, <em>The Guardian</em> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/kenya-olympic-doubt-wada-non-compliant">reports</a>. The decision to ban Kenya from participating in the summer games is up to the International Olympic Committee.</p>

<p>The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF), the global governing body for athletics, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/nov/17/iaaf-kenya-investigation-doping-allegations">investigated</a> doping allegations in Kenya last year. Dick Pound, the former president of WADA and chair of its independent committee, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/nov/17/kenya-doping-problem-dick-pound-concern">said</a> in November that it is &ldquo;pretty clear that there is a lot of performance-enhancing drugs being used&rdquo; in Kenya. Pound led the investigation of Russian athletics that in November <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/us-athletics-corruption-idUSKCN0SY1NG20151109">alleged</a> widespread doping by athletes and corruption among officials. In response, the IAAF <a href="http://www.iaaf.org/news/press-release/iaaf-araf-suspended">suspended</a> Russia&rsquo;s membership in the association. WADA officials were sent Russia to <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/05/olympic-games-russia-rio-dick-pound-wada-president">overhaul its anti-doping practices</a> in time for Rio, and IAAF will decide on Russia&rsquo;s membership in June.</p>

<p><em>Runner&rsquo;s World</em> detailed last year the reports of alleged cheating among Russian and Kenyan athletes:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Between 2001 and 2012, some 146 Olympic and world championships medalists in <a href="http://store.nike.com/us/en_us/pw/mens-running-shoes/7puZ8yzZoi3?ipp=112" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">running</a> and walking events 800 meters and longer had blood test results that were grounds for suspicion of <a href="http://www.runnersworld.com/tag/performance-enhancing-drugs">performance-enhancing drug use</a>, according to German TV station <a href="http://www.daserste.de/information/reportage-dokumentation/dokus/videos/geheimsache-doping-engl-version-100.html" target="_blank">ARD&rsquo;s new documentary</a> <em>Doping&ndash;Top Secret: The Shadowy World of Athletics</em>, and simultaneous reporting <a href="http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/news/uk_news/thedopingscandal/article1588373.ece" target="_blank">by the <em>Sunday Times</em></a>.</p>

<p>Fifty-five of those said to have suspicious blood results were gold medalists. More than 80 of the suspicious medals were won by Russians, and 18 were won by Kenyans. In a 5,000-athlete database maintained by the International Association of Athletics Federations, 800 were judged by two Australia-based experts to have blood values that suggested illegal drug use, mainly indicative of the blood booster EPO.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Kenyan athletes <a href="http://www.bbc.com/sport/olympics/2012/medals/countries/kenya/sports/athletics">won</a> 11 medals in the 2012 Olympic Games in London, nearly all in track events. Russia <a href="http://www.bbc.com/sport/olympics/2012/medals/countries/russian-federation">won</a> 18.</p>

<p>For all the downsides of binge-watching and <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/04/the-revolution-will-be-streamed/477027/">serialized storytelling</a>, Netflix has done much to revitalize many moribund TV genres with its original programming. The <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2015/04/daredevil/390294/">comic-book show</a>, the <a href="http://www.vox.com/2015/8/23/9186237/bojack-horseman-netflix-interview">grownup cartoon</a>, and the <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/04/unbreakable-kimmy-schmidt-returns-more-madcap-than-ever/478476/">network sitcom</a> have all found surprising new angles thanks to the streaming service. But its new offering <em>Chelsea</em>&mdash;hosted by Chelsea Handler&mdash;is tackling an even steeper challenge: turning the late-night talk show, the most staid, old-school television format around, into something fresh and exciting. The series makes a noble effort, but from the look of its first episodes, it hasn&rsquo;t yet figured out a way to stand out from its competitors.</p>

<aside class="callout-placeholder" data-source="curated"></aside>

<p>Handler is a veteran at the talk-show game, and her long-running series on E!, <em>Chelsea Lately</em>, was more anarchic than her network-TV rivals, with its permanent roundtable of L.A. comedians riffing on pop culture and reality TV. Her Netflix series, which will release episodes every Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, applies that freewheeling conversational style to more serious topics&mdash;education reform, tech innovation&mdash;while retaining some of the medium&rsquo;s classic formatting. But more often than not, the combination is awkward rather than transformative.</p>

<p>Part of the problem is Handler&rsquo;s insistence that she&rsquo;s doing something radically different. &ldquo;I&rsquo;ve learned that I don&rsquo;t want to do a monologue anymore,&rdquo; she said in the first episode&rsquo;s monologue, delivered to a laughing audience. &ldquo;I know it seems like a monologue, but this is not a monologue. It&rsquo;s an explanation. And if you don&rsquo;t know the difference, then you can log out, or log off, or fuck off, or whatever ... I&rsquo;m a late-show host that doesn&rsquo;t want to be tied down by time, or television, or even hosting.&rdquo;</p>

<p>That&rsquo;d make more sense if <em>Chelsea </em>didn&rsquo;t feel like such a classic late show, through and through. After her opening monologue, which disses the idea of an opening monologue, Handler transfers to a desk and makes a few jokes about the upcoming election, before cutting to a pre-taped sketch poking gentle fun at her new network. There&rsquo;s nothing here viewers haven&rsquo;t seen before&mdash;but that&rsquo;s not entirely Handler&rsquo;s fault. The late-night talk show really only hinges on two things: It airs late at night, and its stars and guests talk about current events, be they frivolous or weighty. What&rsquo;s there to revolutionize?</p>

<aside class="pullquote instapaper_ignore"><em>Chelsea </em>feels like a classic late-night show, through and through.</aside>

<p>As with many Netflix shows, the biggest difference the viewer might immediately notice in <em>Chelsea </em>is the lack of ad breaks. With network shows, commercial breaks have come to inform the structure of each episode: They demand that a guest fit an anecdote into six minutes, or that the viewer sit through five ad breaks before watching the musical performance or stand-up set they might have tuned in for. Not so with <em>Chelsea</em>. Bored by the opening sketch, but interested in Handler&rsquo;s discussion with Education Secretary John King? Just skip ahead to that. If a panel runs a little longer than expected, the show can keep it all in, since running times don&rsquo;t matter much (episode one is 37 minutes long, episode two is 33). Meanwhile, even premium-cable talk shows like HBO&rsquo;s <em>Last Week Tonight</em>, which also don&rsquo;t have to worry about ads, still have to fit within a half-hour block.</p>

<p><em>Chelsea </em>is also notable for its &ldquo;near-live&rdquo; status (it records the Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday of each week it airs), while all other network talk shows, from Stephen Colbert to Jimmy Fallon to Trevor Noah, tape hours before they air. Since joining Netflix, Handler <a href="http://variety.com/2015/digital/news/chelsea-handler-rips-e-tv-experience-1201436471/">has talked</a> about how bored she got with the demands of her E! show and the necessity of discussing the latest life updates of reality stars and hot items from gossip blogs. She envisions <em>Chelsea </em>as <em>60 Minutes</em> but &ldquo;faster and cooler,&rdquo; and the first two episodes of the show try to accomplish that by throwing wonks like King or TED Talks founder Chris Anderson together with celebrities like Drew Barrymore and Gwyneth Paltrow. It provokes some insightful moments&mdash;and some wince-inducing ones, like Handler&rsquo;s<strong> </strong>attempt to freestyle rap with Pitbull minutes after he tearfully talked about the educators who had an impact on his adolescence.</p>

<p>Late night has strict formatting for a reason: The whiplash between straightforward comedy and insightful, honest interviews can otherwise be too much for audiences. Still, few talk shows know from the start how to nail the tone they&rsquo;re aiming for. Fortunately, Handler has time to figure that out&mdash;the show will air 90 episodes this year, three per week, throwing together eclectic groups of guests. <em>Chelsea</em> may be off to a shaky start, but for those who want to wait for the show to find its feet before checking out some episodes, there should be an interesting backlog of segments in a few weeks. It might not exactly overhaul the late-night format, but few shows are in a better position to do so.</p>

<p>Even the biggest fans of the rapper Azealia Banks&rsquo;s music&mdash;<a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/03/azealia-banks-slay-z-donald-trump-review/475707/">I&rsquo;d count myself among them</a>&mdash;have to admit, by now, that her larger ongoing cultural significance stems from her tweets rather than her music. At a time when sensitivity&mdash;or &ldquo;political correctness&rdquo;&mdash;is a hot topic, Banks has played the unique role of reminding people that there&rsquo;s no partisan monopoly on hatefulness. She supports Trump but also parts of far-left ideology; she&rsquo;s flung hate speech at nearly every identity group imaginable, with her latest flare-up slurring the singer Zayn Malik for being Pakistani and the actress Skai Jackson for being young. This time, the results are that she&rsquo;s been dropped from a U.K. music festival and&mdash;this is big, though possibly coincidentally timed&mdash;suspended from Twitter.</p>

<aside class="callout-placeholder" data-source="curated"></aside>

<p>It feels like satire come to life that her long-awaited reckoning would come only after insulting an insanely popular ex-boy-bander like Malik. The racism and homophobia on display wasn&rsquo;t new for her; the lesson would seem to be that the one group you never want to offend is One Direction fans. If you want to find a deeper lesson, though, you can: Banks&rsquo;s final (for now) Twitter tirade was a perfectly incoherent masterclass in showing how we end up with so many people spewing hate speech at strangers online.</p>

<p>The incident began with Banks posting a side-by-side comparison on Instagram of Malik&rsquo;s new music video with an old one of hers. The point was that he was jacking her aesthetic, though the picture of skinny shirtless Malik next to Banks in a bra seemed like a wink that she wasn&rsquo;t being all that serious. Ditto for <a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/BFO6qsqn1by/?taken-by=azealiabanks&amp;hl=en">the caption</a>: &ldquo;I&rsquo;m not mad about this though. Zayn is a cutie pie.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Soon after, Malik tweeted &ldquo;I see you reaching but I don&rsquo;t care&rdquo; and &ldquo;My @&rsquo;s too good for you.&rdquo; He might have been referring to Banks but he might not have been. She assumed he was, replying, &ldquo;dude, I make better music than you. Simmer down with that fake white boy rebellion and that wannabe beiber swag.&rdquo;</p>

<aside class="pullquote instapaper_ignore">She reached for the cruelest weapon available.</aside>

<p>From there, she underwent a pretty dramatic devolution. The next tweet called him a &ldquo;curry scented bitch,&rdquo; leading the online Desi community to quickly turned #curryscentedbitch into <a href="https://www.buzzfeed.com/sahilrizwan/curry-scented-post">a pride slogan</a>. The one after: &ldquo;imma start calling you punjab you dirty bitch.&rdquo; <em>Imma start&mdash;</em>in other words, she&rsquo;s <em>choosing</em> to go there. She&rsquo;s reaching for the cruelest weapon available. Unvarnished racism blended with attempts at a wider critique as her tweets lectured him that he&rsquo;d only ever been a token in One Direction: &ldquo;Do you understand that you are a sand nigger who emulates white boys&rsquo; renditions of black male hood?&rdquo;</p>

<p>She later posted a textbook non-apology for her freakout&mdash;&ldquo;Remember that offense is never given, it is only taken. I apologize to everyone who TOOK offense.&rdquo; More interesting was her <a href="http://www.vulture.com/2016/05/azealia-banks-was-trying-to-remind-zayn-hes-poc.html">longer explanation</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>I said what I said to Zayn because I was angry. He felt as if he was too good to acknowledge me yet not too good to copy my creativity. I had to remind him that we&rsquo;re both in the same boat in this industry and people of color by reminding him that no matter what you may think of yourself, the world still sees you as &ldquo;other,&rdquo; as they see me.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>This <em>might</em> have made sense if she hadn&rsquo;t been the one employing disgusting slurs in exactly the way that the racists she was supposedly exposing might use them. The first two lines, suggesting she turned to hate speech out of anger and powerlessness, seems like as good an explanation as anyone is going to get for what leads someone to send so many mixed (and horrifying) messages over the years. Twitter has made it easy for her and others to air their ugliest feelings with the ugliest words possible; it hasn&rsquo;t ever seemed to make those feelings go away. For now it&rsquo;s doing the next best thing, which is taking her words offline.</p>

<p dir="ltr">On January 20, 2016, Mohammed Ali Abdullah Bwazir stood with shackles on his ankles, wrists, and waist at the bottom of a ramp leading up to a U.S. Air Force cargo plane. The plane was going to take him, along with two other Guantanamo Bay prisoners, to an undisclosed southern European nation. Bwazir, who is either 35 or 36 and is from Yemen, had been cleared for release after spending 14 years in the U.S. prison in Cuba.</p>

<p>He refused to get on the plane.</p>

<p>&ldquo;He wasn&rsquo;t angry. He wasn&rsquo;t acting out. He was very calm,&rdquo; Army Colonel David Heath, the Guantanamo prison warden, later <a href="http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/article59826521.html">recalled</a> to Carol Rosenberg, the <em>Miami Herald</em> reporter<strong> </strong>who has been covering the prison since it first opened. Bwazir&rsquo;s lawyer, John Chandler, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/22/us/politics/guantanamo-detainee-refuses-release-offer.html">told</a> <em>The New York Times</em> the man was depressed and feared living in a country where he had no family. Bwazir wanted to go to Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, or Indonesia, where he has a mother, brothers, uncles, and aunts. Faced instead with a new life in Europe, he chose to return to his cell.</p>

<p>Bwazir&rsquo;s case highlights the complexities of emptying the prison opened after 9/11 to house dangerous terrorism suspects. The potential release of its captives carries a host of legal, political, and diplomatic implications. They illustrate why two presidents have been unsuccessful in closing the detention camp at Guantanamo Bay, despite criticism of the treatment, including waterboarding, that some of the inmates underwent.</p>

<p>About 780 inmates have been held at Guantanamo since it opened in 2002. Today, 80 remain.</p>

<p>Most have not been charged with any crimes, according to <a href="http://projects.nytimes.com/guantanamo">a comprehensive database</a> maintained by <em>The New York Times</em>. All are men, mostly in their 30s and 40s. The youngest is about 30 or 31; the oldest is 68. Most have been there for more than 13 or 14 years. Some have gone on hunger strikes and were force-fed with liquid nutrients through nasal tubes.</p>

<p>The inmates come from 17 countries and the<strong> </strong>Palestinian<strong> </strong>territories. The majority of inmates&mdash;43&mdash;are from Yemen. Eight are from Afghanistan, and six each from Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. The rest are from Tajikistan, Tunisia, Iraq, Algeria, Indonesia, Kenya, Libya, Malaysia, Mauritania, Morocco, Russia, and Somalia. One inmate&rsquo;s native country is unknown.</p>

<p>At least 26 inmates, including Bwazir, have been cleared for release; a review board system President<strong> </strong>Obama created by executive order in 2011 has determined they no longer pose a security threat to the United States. This week, the board <a href="http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/guantanamo/article76578262.html">cleared</a> for release<strong> </strong>Salem Ahmed Hadi, a suspected jihadist who left Yemen for Afghanistan before 9/11 and arrived at Guantanamo in its second week of existence. It was his fifth time before the board, which had previously rejected releasing him.</p>

<p>At least 43 inmates are being held indefinitely and have not been recommended for release by the review boards. These indefinite detainees are known as the &ldquo;forever prisoners,&rdquo; the captives deemed too dangerous to release but who have not been charged with any crimes. Indefinite detention without trial is illegal under the Geneva Conventions, but the Bush administration <a href="http://www.bu.edu/today/2013/gitmo-the-legal-mess-behind-the-ethical-mess/">argued</a> that international laws did not apply to the &ldquo;unlawful enemy combatants&rdquo; who were taken to Guantanamo.</p>

<p>Seven inmates have been <a href="http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/guantanamo/article2163210.html">charged with war crimes</a> in Guantanamo&rsquo;s military commissions, the judicial system set up by the Bush administration and tweaked by the Obama administration. They include Khalid Sheik Mohammed, the alleged organizer of the 9/11 terrorist attacks, and his four alleged co-conspirators. The others are Abd al Rahim al-Nashiri, a Saudi detainee charged for allegedly organizing the bombing of a U.S. Navy destroyer in Yemen in 2000 that killed 17 sailors, and Abd al Hadi al Iraqi, an Iraqi detainee who allegedly led al-Qaeda&rsquo;s military operations from 2002 to 2004.</p>

<p>Three inmates have been convicted of war crimes, but the conviction of one was overturned on appeal. Majid Khan, a Pakistani native who once lived in Baltimore, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/guantanamo-detainee-majid-khan-pleads-guilty-promises-cooperation/2012/02/29/gIQAVuIaiR_story.html">pleaded guilty</a> to war crimes in 2012, acknowledging he returned to Pakistan after 9/11 to work for Khalid Sheik Mohammed. <a href="http://projects.nytimes.com/guantanamo/detainees/768-ahmed-muhammed-haza-al-darbi">Ahmed Muhammed Haza al-Darbi</a>, a Saudi citizen, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/21/us/guantanamo-detainee-ahmed-muhammed-haza-al-darbi.html">pleaded guilty</a> in 2014 over the 2002 al-Qaeda attack on a French oil tanker off the coast of Yemen. Ali Hamza Ahmad Suliman al-Bahlul, a Saudi citizen accused of being Osama bin Laden&rsquo;s &ldquo;media secretary,&rdquo; was <a href="https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/03/05/ali-hamza-ahmad-suliman-al-bahlul">convicted</a> in 2008 of conspiracy, terrorism-related charges,<strong> </strong>and other charges. The D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned his conviction in 2013, saying the crimes of which he<strong> </strong>was convicted were not recognized as war crimes at the time he committed them.</p>

<p>The White House&rsquo;s push to shutter Guantanamo for good began a decade ago. In May 2006, President George W. Bush <a href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/bush-says-he-wants-to-close-guantanamo/">said</a> he wanted to close the detention center. Two years later, Obama made the closure of the prison one of his campaign promises. In his first days in office, Obama <a href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/obama-upends-bush-will-close-guantanamo/">issued</a> an executive order to close the prison within a year. He has since vowed to shut it down before he leaves office.</p>

<p dir="ltr">The Bush administration released about <a href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/02/02/AR2010020203883.html">540 detainees</a> without charge. The Obama administration has released <a href="http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/resource/facts-about-transfer-guantanamo-detainees">158</a>. Detainees have gone to countries willing to accept them, <a href="http://projects.nytimes.com/guantanamo/transfer-countries">58 nations</a> in all, according to the <em>Times</em> database. Afghanistan and Saudi Arabia have accepted the most at 203 and 134, respectively. Pakistan has accepted 63. Five Taliban detainees were released in the swap that freed Army Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl from five years of captivity in Afghanistan and Pakistan. Nations on six continents have accepted Guantanamo&rsquo;s prisoners. Nine have died in the camp, five of them by suicide, according to U.S. officials.</p>

<p dir="ltr">Detainees do not choose where they are released. &ldquo;We&rsquo;re not a travel agency,&rdquo; Lee Wolosky, the State Department&rsquo;s special envoy for the Guantanamo closure, <a href="http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/article59826521.html">told</a> the <em>Herald</em>&rsquo;s Rosenberg, after Bwazir asked to be taken back to his cell earlier this year. &ldquo;We&rsquo;re not here to fulfill every wish and desire of a resettlee.&rdquo; The U.S. no longer transfers detainees to Yemen because of the worsening political and security climates and an active a-Qaeda affiliate in the country. U.S. law restricts transfers to countries whose security situations are considered unstable, including Libya, Syria, Yemen and Somalia. In February, Saudi Arabia <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2016/04/16/9-gitmo-detainees-sent-saudi-arabia-80-prisoners-remain/83127414/">agreed</a> to accept non-citizens from Guantanamo for the first time.</p>

<p dir="ltr">Since 2009, Obama has sought to transfer detainees to detention facilities in the U.S. But congressional Republicans have repeatedly blocked those attempts, passing legislation that <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/senate-ndaa-closing-guantanamo_56421b7ee4b0307f2caf060e">prohibits</a> the use of government funds to transfer prisoners to American soil and the construction of facilities to house them. Only two detainees have been transferred to the United States: Yaser Esam Hamdi, in April 2002, and Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani in June 2009. Hamdi, who is a citizen of both the U.S. and Saudi Arabia and was born in Louisiana, was held at a naval brig in Charleston, South Carolina, until October 2004 when he was <a href="http://projects.nytimes.com/guantanamo/detainees/9-yaser-esam-hamdi">repatriated</a> to Saudi Arabia. Ghailani, a Tanzanian, was <a href="http://projects.nytimes.com/guantanamo/detainees/10012-ahmed-khalfan-ghailani">transferred</a> to the U.S. in 2009 and remains at the federal super-maximum security prison in Fremont, Colorado.</p>

<p dir="ltr">In February, the administration, in a final proposal to Congress for Guantanamo&rsquo;s closure, <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-guantanamo-costs-idUSKCN0VW1NB">proposed</a> sending detainees to 13 potential sites on U.S. soil but did not identify the facilities. Last year, Pentagon officials <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2015/10/guantanamo-bay-colorado/410296/">surveyed</a> potential candidates, visiting federal prisons in Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, and Charleston, South Carolina, as well as state and federal facilities in Florence, Colorado.</p>

<p dir="ltr">Opponents of closing Guantanamo argue detainees return to terrorist activity when released. Top Republican lawmakers and foreign-policy hawks, including Senators John McCain and Lindsey Graham, say 30 percent of freed detainees become terrorists. Bu Congress-mandated reports from the administration&rsquo;s intelligence officials <a href="http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2015/jan/15/john-mccain/mccain-30-past-guantanamo-detainees-re-enter-fight/">show</a> the rate of confirmed recidivism is about 17 percent. Obama has said Guantanamo serves as a &ldquo;recruiting tool&rdquo; for other extremist militant groups, like the Islamic State, but experts who study jihadist propaganda say the camp is <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/02/is-guantanamo-a-terrorist-recruitment-tool/470640/">not featured prominently in jihadist materials</a>.</p>

<p dir="ltr">The first 20 prisoners of Guantanamo Bay <a href="http://edition.cnn.com/2002/WORLD/asiapcf/central/01/11/ret.detainee.transfer/index.html">arrived</a> in Cuba on January 11, 2002. In the short months after Bush declared a war on terrorism, the U.S. military had captured 45 fighters from al-Qaeda and the Taliban in the Middle East, and it needed a place to put them. Officials ruled out Guam after its citizens raised concerns about the presence of terrorism suspects, and settled on the U.S. naval base on Cuba&rsquo;s southeastern tip&mdash;&ldquo;the least worst place we could have selected,&rdquo; as former U.S. Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld once <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2001/12/28/us/nation-challenged-detention-camp-us-hold-taliban-detainees-least-worst-place.html">described</a> it. Back then, the base was capable of housing 100 detainees, and the first captives were held in the steel-and-wire cages as the detention center was expanded.</p>

<p dir="ltr">More than a decade later, the sprawling camp has enough facilities to house hundreds of prisoners. Military personnel vastly outnumber captives. The annual cost to taxpayers of maintaining the camp was <a href="https://www.aclu.org/infographic/wasted-opportunities-cost-detention-operations-guantanamo-bay">$454 million</a> in 2013.</p>

<p dir="ltr">The <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/us-guantanamo-hearings-factbox-idUSN1148106920080411">last known arrival</a> to the prison was Muhammed Rahim al-Afghani in 2008, an Afghan described as a high-level al-Qaeda operative. The latest release was in April of this year, when nine Yemeni prisoners were <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-guantanamo-idUSKCN0XD0ZU">transferred</a> to Saudi Arabia.</p>

<p dir="ltr">In 2013, Rosenberg, the <em>Herald</em> reporter, <a href="http://www.poynter.org/2013/miami-herald-reporter-covers-guantanamo-bay-for-12-years-with-no-end-in-sight/214562/">told</a> Poynter she was assigned to report the Guantanamo story &ldquo;start to finish.&rdquo; She doesn&rsquo;t expect Obama to meet his self-imposed deadline. &ldquo;I thought it would be closed when Obama was elected, but as it stands, it could be that we will just be waiting for the last guy to die before it closes,&rdquo; she said.</p>

<p>The latest chapter from George R. R. Martin&rsquo;s long-gestating novel <em>The Winds of Winter</em>, released on the <a href="http://www.georgerrmartin.com/excerpt-from-the-winds-of-winter/">author&rsquo;s website</a> yesterday, is typically tantalizing material. Like the rest his <em>Song of Ice and Fire</em> series, it&rsquo;s told entirely from the point of view of a specific character&mdash;this time Princess Arianne Martell, the heiress to the kingdom of Dorne, as she ponders a new challenger to the Iron Throne of Westeros. It adds more context to two crucial stories and lends further depth to one of Martin&rsquo;s most dynamic female characters. It also has nothing to do with the hit HBO series that the novels inspired.</p>

<aside class="callout-placeholder" data-source="curated"></aside>

<p><em>Game of Thrones,</em> currently in its sixth season, has largely diverged from Martin&rsquo;s books, telling stories past their current end point in the completed novels as the annual demands of TV production outpace the author&rsquo;s decades-long writing process. Fans have worried that the show, which creators David Benioff and D.B. Weiss have said will probably end after <a href="http://variety.com/2016/tv/news/game-of-thrones-end-date-season-8-1201752746/">two more truncated seasons</a>, will spoil Martin&rsquo;s grand conclusion. But as every chapter released from <em>The Winds of Winter </em>shows, including this latest check-in with Arianne, there&rsquo;s nothing to fear. Martin is telling tales of characters the show&rsquo;s viewers will never meet, on quests that will never make it to the screen. And the show is actually beginning to work toward an ending, which leaves Martin free to do something else entirely.</p>

<p>Fans have also long accepted that <em>Game of Thrones </em>will finish before every chapter of <em>A Song of Ice and Fire </em>hits bookstores. Even if Martin had finished <em>The Winds of Winter </em>last year as he intended, he would have had to turn around the seventh and supposedly final entry within a year or two to beat the show. He hasn&rsquo;t worked at that pace in a long time: The shortest turnaround between books was just under two years between the second and third novels in the series, and the last entry came out in 2011, the year <em>Game of Thrones </em>premiered. But when <a href="http://grrm.livejournal.com/465247.html">Martin announced</a> to fans that <em>Winds of Winter </em>wouldn&rsquo;t be done in time for season six of <em>Game of Thrones</em>, he tried to reassure readers. &ldquo;Some of the &lsquo;spoilers&rsquo; you may encounter in season six may not be spoilers at all ... because the show and the books have diverged, and will continue to do so,&rdquo; he wrote.</p>

<p>The new Arianne chapter, which Martin has read aloud at fan conventions, is a perfect example of that divergence, coming at an opportune moment since the show has begun killing pivotal characters. Arianne, the heiress of Dorne, isn&rsquo;t a character in the show at all&mdash;she was replaced by a male heir, Trystane, a minor character in the books. His elevation <a href="http://mashable.com/2014/07/29/game-of-thrones-arianna-martell/#fD4ENjaGYaq8">sparked outcry</a> from fans who thought the show was losing a compelling female leader, but in Martin&rsquo;s pages she endures, negotiating the future of her kingdom and reckoning with a new contender to the throne.</p>

<p>That character, the pretender Aegon Targaryen, also isn&rsquo;t in the show. Neither is his companion Jon Connington, who&rsquo;s discussed extensively in the new chapter. Martin has also released chapters about Stannis Baratheon and Barristan Selmy (both killed off by HBO last season), and Victarion Greyjoy (who doesn&rsquo;t exist on the show and likely never will). As the show came closer to overtaking Martin&rsquo;s books, he made more and more references to the &ldquo;butterfly effect&rdquo; of TV plotting, where <em>Game of Thrones</em>&rsquo;s attempts to simplify the grander story arc would only lead to bigger differences between the books and show. What first felt like a cop-out now feels on point: Readers are no longer worried the show&rsquo;s going to spoil the novels, just that it&rsquo;ll move forward clumsily with its adaptation efforts.</p>

<aside class="pullquote instapaper_ignore">Martin is telling tales of characters show viewers will never meet, on quests that will never make it to the screen.</aside>

<p>Consider a semi-humorous <a href="https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1833467562/fixing-dorne">Kickstarter campaign</a> to &ldquo;fix&rdquo; the show&rsquo;s Dorne plotline, which was largely dispatched in the opening episode of this season. In Martin&rsquo;s books, Dorne is a powerful sector of Westeros under the rule of the infirm but wise Prince Doran, who&rsquo;s scheming to position his children for greatness as the realm falls into chaos. On the show, Doran was an ineffectual fool, eventually betrayed and murdered by his brother&rsquo;s paramour. His death scene, and the subsequent murder of his son, felt like Benioff and Weiss washing their hands of a plotline they never quite knew how to weave into the larger story. The Kickstarter campaign says it needs $20 million to replicate the show&rsquo;s style and production value and shoot enough material to paper over the problem areas. The campaign&rsquo;s creators probably aren&rsquo;t going to make it (currently, backers have pledged almost $24,000), but their project captures just how strongly many readers feel about the show&rsquo;s new direction.</p>

<p>For all the complaints from hardcore fans, Benioff and Weiss are working with admirable intent this year, and they&rsquo;re wise to point <em>Game of Thrones </em>toward an ending. Dorne may be an intriguing location in the books, but it never worked for the show, so it had to go. Characters like Stannis, Barristan, Roose Bolton, and others were compelling figures who weren&rsquo;t indispensable to the show&rsquo;s outcome, so it&rsquo;s no surprise they were all killed off in typically bloody HBO fashion.</p>

<p>Martin, on the other hand, may never even finish his grand opus. When he began writing <em>A Song of Ice and Fire </em>in 1991, it was planned <a href="http://winteriscoming.net/2015/02/05/george-rr-martin-original-game-of-thrones-pitch/">as three books</a>. The fourth book turned into a volume of unpublishable length and was split into two, taking over a decade to be released. <a href="http://www.ew.com/article/2011/07/22/fantasy-king/3">Martin still swears</a> there are only two more entries left in the series. His plot meanderings across his fictional continents may frustrate some readers, but the approach is also why so many were drawn to the detailed world he created in the first place. For fans dissatisfied with the show&rsquo;s pared-down move toward an endgame, there&rsquo;ll be no shortage of richness in the books to come&mdash;as long as they don&rsquo;t mind waiting several more years.</p>

<p>The U.S. Marine Corps has allowed two female service members to join the infantry, marking the first time women will hold jobs in the combat force.</p>

<p>The Marines have approved one woman to become a rifleman and another to become a machine gunner, <em>The Military Times</em> <a href="http://www.militarytimes.com/story/military/2016/05/09/female-marine-rifleman-machine-gunner-headed-infantry/84156638/">reported</a> Monday. Both women requested the jobs.</p>

<p>&ldquo;The Corps applauds the time and efforts of those Marines who volunteered,&rdquo; said Captain Philip Kulczewski, a Marine spokesman at the Pentagon. More from <em>The Military Times:</em></p>

<blockquote>
<p>Since no women have graduated from the service&rsquo;s Infantry Officer Course, female Marine or Navy officers assigned to infantry battalions will serve in support roles. The 30th female Marine to attempt IOC left her class on April 21 after she was unable to complete two hikes. She has the opportunity to attempt the course again in July.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>The Marines did not release the women&rsquo;s names. Under the service&rsquo;s gender-integration policy, two female officers will be assigned to the infantry unit 90 days before its new members arrive. &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>The U.S. military <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2015/12/women-in-the-military/418680/">announced</a> in December it would open all combat jobs in every branch of the armed forces to women starting this year. &ldquo;They&rsquo;ll be able to serve as Army Rangers and Green Berets, Navy SEALs, Marine Corps infantry, Air Force parajumpers, and everything else that was previously open only to men,&rdquo; U.S. Defense Secretary Ash Carter said at the time.</p>

<p>Carter <a href="http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/story/military/2016/04/15/first-female-marine-applies-join-infantry/83073068/">approved</a> the Marine Corps&rsquo; gender integration plan in March, making 233 women who graduated from infantry training and other military occupational-specialty schools eligible to apply for combat jobs.</p>

<p>The U.S. military will see several firsts for female service members this year. The Army <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2016/04/15/army-women-new-rules-infantry-armor-officers/83036812/">announced</a> last month that 22 women would be commissioned as infantry and armor officers for the first time. A female staff sergeant will <a href="http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/story/military/2016/03/28/female-admin-marine-attempt-marsoc-training-summer/82347390/">attempt</a> the six-week course of the Marine Corps&rsquo;s special-operations command this summer; if she completes training, she could become the first female critical-skills operator. The Navy has begun collecting applications for SEAL training from men and women, but <a href="http://www.navytimes.com/story/military/2016/04/19/navy-seals-now-open-women-but-none-has-stepped-forward/82982558/">no women have applied</a> as of this month.</p>

<p>I&rsquo;d like to say my 12-year-old son Justice was enjoying every second of the American history lesson my wife and I were giving him. It was Independence Day weekend last summer, and we were driving up Jefferson Davis Highway from Richmond, Virginia. I pointed out the <a href="http://www.citylab.com/design/2015/07/why-memorializing-americas-history-of-racism-matters/397781/">Confederate road markers along the way</a> to teach my son about the Civil War. My wife and I took turns Googling the names and landmarks mentioned on the monuments and summarizing out loud. Justice was also on his iPhone, but not paying us much attention&mdash;I could tell by the way his fingers kept rapidly tapping the touchscreen that he was playing one of his games. I even tried the very Dad approach of using pop-culture references to grab his attention&mdash;&ldquo;So Justice, this spot over here was like the Confederate Army&rsquo;s <em>no flex zone</em>&mdash;you know, like Rae Sremmurd?&rdquo;&mdash;to no avail.</p>

<aside class="callout-placeholder" data-source="special-report"></aside>

<p>For a second, though, I thought perhaps it wasn&rsquo;t my corny presentation that was turning Justice off, but rather the macabre details about war and slavery. But he disabused me of the notion when I brought it up&mdash;he didn&rsquo;t feel threatened, likely because the reality of growing up black in America today is in many ways much scarier<strong> </strong>than the tales of rebel generals of yesteryear. That&rsquo;s not to say the stories of the ghosts of Confederate militants and Klan vigilantes aren&rsquo;t also haunting, or disturbing, in their own right. Despite my brief misgivings, I&rsquo;d never hesitated before then when it came to sharing the ugliness of America&rsquo;s racial history with my son. That&rsquo;s probably because I wasn&rsquo;t spooked by these kinds of stories growing up, just as my parents hadn&rsquo;t been unnerved about exposing me to them.</p>

<p>One of the ways they introduced me to these stories was through comic books, though not the kind my son reads today. The comics of my youth weren&rsquo;t from the DC or Marvel universes: The first graphic novels I ever encountered were about black figures from history, courtesy of the <a href="https://www.mycomicshop.com/search?TID=346671">Golden Legacy comics</a> first published by Bertram A. Fitzgerald, Jr. in the 1960s and &rsquo;70s. None of my peers or friends got the same introduction to comics I did, but my parents were pretty mindful about the media I consumed as a child. I guess they figured if I were going to lay eyes on storyboards filled with graphic violence, they might as well have been about black history, which itself has no shortage of savagery.</p>

<p>I was probably in the 4th grade when my mother started bringing the books home from a five-and-dime store in the city. Each Golden Legacy comic was basically an animated biography of figures such as the early D.C. urban planner <a href="http://golden-legacy.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/vol04.jpg">Benjamin Banneker</a> and the arctic explorer <a href="http://golden-legacy.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/vol05.jpg">Matthew Henson</a>. (I&rsquo;m pretty sure I read the whole series.) At risk of sounding all <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooley_High"><em>Coolie Hotep High</em></a>, it&rsquo;s thanks to those books that the first comic superheroes I ever knew were Crispus Attucks, Harriet Tubman, and Frederick Douglass.</p>

<p>Of course, I knew who Superman, Batman, and Wonder Woman were, though mostly from cartoons. Those narratives were cool, but not one scene from any of their story arcs resonated with me like the scene from Golden Legacy&rsquo;s <em>The Saga of Harriet Tubman &ldquo;The Moses of Her People</em><em>&rdquo;</em> where a slave-master struck Tubman in the head with an iron weight. The illustrations weren&rsquo;t super pulpy, but they didn&rsquo;t skimp on the violence either. The artist was able to convey in that scene just how painful the iron blast was: The nasty gash it left on her face made me wince like nothing from Superman did.</p>

<p>Yet the artist also illustrated the narrative in a way that subtly suggested the crushing blow somehow knocked supernatural powers into Tubman that allowed her to envision things many of her enslaved loved ones couldn&rsquo;t&mdash;like freedom. In my mind, those scenes were like the spider bite to Peter Parker. As Tubman led group after group of enslaved black people through the Underground Railroad to liberation at the end of the book, she became the only Wonder Woman that made sense to me.</p>

<aside class="pullquote instapaper_ignore">The first comic superheroes I ever knew were Crispus Attucks, Harriet Tubman, and Frederick Douglass.</aside>

<p>After that, I didn&rsquo;t want to read anything about slavery that didn&rsquo;t feature Tubman&rsquo;s heroic triumphs. The Golden Legacy comic <em>Crispus Attucks and the Minutemen</em> had the same effect on me, with its portrayal of how the Revolutionary War jumped off with a black man and his clan at the front. And after I&rsquo;d read the two-part Golden Legacy series on Frederick Douglass, you couldn&rsquo;t tell me I didn&rsquo;t know everything that I needed to know about the Civil War.</p>

<p>But, of course, there was much more for me to learn; the Golden Legacy comic books were only my entry point into a deeper well of knowledge. My father, an avid reader, stacked plenty of books about black history around the house that I was more than happy to gormandize as I grew older. These works were filled with the thoughts and ideas of black men like Malcolm X, Marcus Garvey, and John Henrik Clarke&mdash;all of them looking to correct the historical doctrines that sought to paint slavery as an otherwise benign and painless institution. The racial-violence quotient in this literature was far beyond anything I read or saw in the Golden Legacy stories.</p>

<p>In a recent conversation, my father told me he wasn&rsquo;t really ever worried about my young exposure to such weighty and morbid accounts of racism. Having grown up without his own father around, he said, he thought it was important that I rummage through those books to understand &ldquo;the lay of the land&rdquo; so I could raise questions about what I learned. &ldquo;Whatever you were exploring back then, if you came to me, I welcomed it as a necessary conversation,&rdquo; he told me. &ldquo;And I was more than happy to entertain that and to tell you that this is what you need to know for survival.&rdquo;</p>

<p>My mother also said she had no anxiety about my exposure to America&rsquo;s racial past. I can&rsquo;t remember a time in my youth when she didn&rsquo;t keep a healthy crop of <em>Ebony</em> magazines around the house, and there was a time when I saw, in one issue, the infamous open-casket funeral picture of Emmett Till with his swollen, chewed-up face. I learned from reading the article that Till had been beaten to a pulp and lynched by two white men in Mississippi who accused the black teenager of flirting with a white woman. The story shook me up pretty badly, but it didn&rsquo;t cause my mother to start stashing the <em>Ebony</em>s away. When I spoke to her about this recently, she told me she was more concerned about me reading the Encyclopedia Brown series, because of &ldquo;all those ghouls and monsters&rdquo; in the books.</p>

<p>Maybe these childhood experiences were why I had no qualms last summer about pulling over on Jefferson Davis Highway to take my son to view one of the Confederate memorials up close. I risked scaring or scarring him by providing the context for what we were examining: the lynchings, the whippings, the Fugitive Slave Act, the drapetomania enslaved blacks were diagnosed with when they tried to run away from it all.</p>

<p>Justice didn&rsquo;t seem traumatized at all, though. In fact, it seemed to finally be piquing his interest, possibly even piloting some small rage in him. After all, my son was coming up in the age of Trayvon Martin, Michael Brown, Sandra Bland, and the Charleston Nine. In the end, there&rsquo;s very little I can do to shield him from those graphics. The ongoing chronicles of American racial terror are something few, if any, black families have the luxury of avoiding.</p>

                title="Why Stephen Curry Is Captivating"

<p>Last night, I rushed home to watch an NBA playoff game for the first time since the Los Angeles Lakers&ndash;&ndash;the team I&rsquo;ve cheered for my whole life&ndash;&ndash;were last competitive. I watched the Golden State Warriors defeat the Portland Trailblazers, a victory that allows them to advance to the Western Conference Finals. But none of that mattered to me. I just wanted to watch Stephen Curry play.</p>

<p>Why?</p>

<aside class="callout-placeholder" data-source="curated"></aside>

<p>His dominance is part of what&rsquo;s compelling, as when Tiger Woods arrived in the PGA and revealed that golf could be played on a higher level than anyone had ever imagined. Last season, Curry made an impressive 286 three-pointers, securing the all-time NBA record for triples made in a season by beating the next best by 10 shots. He did so in a year in which he won the MVP and his team won an NBA championship. It was reasonable to think he might break his own record, or even reach 300 threes.</p>

<p>Then, this season, Curry made 402 three-pointers!</p>

<p>After a broader assessment of his off-the-charts statistical efficiency, Benjamin Morris of 538 simply declared, &ldquo;<a href="http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/stephen-curry-is-the-revolution/">Stephen Curry Is the Revolution</a>.&rdquo; That article is the best account I&rsquo;ve seen of how unfathomably valuable Curry is to his team. Yet efficiency statistics do not capture how enjoyable a player is to watch as entertainment. As Nikil Saval <a href="https://nplusonemag.com/online-only/online-only/on-kobe-bryant/">noted</a> in his comparison of Tim Duncan and Kobe Bryant:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Though Duncan may end up being accounted the greater player, I am with those who find his post-up, bank-shot style a chore to watch. Very few, even the haters, have felt this way about Kobe in his prime. Every now and again, in my frequent moments of Kobe-doubt, I find myself rewatching one of those YouTube compilations of &ldquo;Top 10 Kobe Clutch Shots&rdquo; to regain my faith. Comparing his various off-balance threes to close out games of Stephen Curry&rsquo;s, the most sublime of shooters, shows the superiority of the latter&rsquo;s game&mdash;his half-court arcs slicing through the air like a knife through bean curd, with unprecedented ease&mdash;but also the peculiar inimitability of Kobe&rsquo;s &hellip; not a single player who is statistically &ldquo;better&rdquo; than Kobe has been as glorious to watch.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>While granting the sentiment, many would argue that Michael Jordan, a statistically better player, was as glorious to watch. David Foster Wallace once <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/20/sports/playmagazine/20federer.html?pagewanted=all&amp;_r=0">called</a> the Chicago Bulls star &ldquo;one of those rare, preternatural athletes who appear to be exempt, at least in part, from certain physical laws,&rdquo; noting that he &ldquo;could not only jump inhumanly high but actually hang there a beat or two longer than gravity allows.&rdquo;</p>

<p>After Jordan&rsquo;s aerial grace and Kobe&rsquo;s leaping theatricality, perhaps there is nothing new under the sun to be seen in dunk contests or improbable drives to basket.</p>

<p>That isn&rsquo;t, anyway, how Curry dazzles, though I would argue that he too seems exempt from certain physical laws: When he&rsquo;s dribbling behind the arc, a defender close at hand, it seems impossible that a 6-foot-three guard could get off a shot. But Curry always can. He dribbles, steps back, and releases the ball so quickly, smoothly, and precisely that one can&rsquo;t quite make sense of it, even in slow motion.</p>

<p>That tremendously impressive feat isn&rsquo;t as visually spectacular as a dribble drive that ends in lift-off, a soaring, twisting flight path to the rim, and a spectacular dunk. And yet, Curry is as compelling as any slam-dunker in his own way&ndash;&ndash;and this is, I think, for two distinct reasons. One is that, unlike Kobe or Shaq or LeBron, Curry does not have a perfect basketball body. That he dominates at his size is both more impressive and more compelling visually. The analog is Lionel Messi, whose highlights are dazzling because he is at once unstoppable <em>and</em> delightfully scrappy.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="370" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/191ceh8MDuI" width="530"></iframe></p>

<p>But in basketball, the best analog, the figure who is most helpful in understanding why Curry is so damn fun to watch, is the last point guard to be as compelling: Magic Johnson.</p>

<p>The Showtime Lakers were among the most entertaining teams to watch in NBA history largely because of Magic&rsquo;s ability to throw passes that defied all expectations. On fast breaks and in transition, he would somehow see teammates that he couldn&rsquo;t have seen unless he had eyes in the back of his head. He&rsquo;d deliver the ball into their hands with no-look passes as visually confounding as a trick-play in football. Even in the half-court offense, he could thread an impossible bounce pass by the legs of defenders at unlikely angles, and with all the force of a bullet. And, of course, he could score, which only helped him to pass more superbly.</p>

<p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="370" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/GoEl2Oo66IY" width="530"></iframe></p>

<p>The effect, for the viewer, was constant suspense. You didn&rsquo;t dare take your eyes off the screen when the ball was in his hands because the potential for surprise was ever-present.</p>

<p>Curry is like that, except that he&rsquo;s a superb passer and a magical scorer. He can dazzle while setting up teammates. But the suspense he gives us flows from the fact that he could shoot anytime, from anywhere. In traffic near the basket? No problem. A defender in his face two steps behind the three-point line? Doesn&rsquo;t matter. Early in the 24-second clock, mere steps past the half court line? Yes, even then and there.</p>

<p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="370" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/gb0wmBUB4cg" width="530"></iframe></p>

<p>People watched the NBA for Magic, and then for Michael and Kobe and LeBron. Now they will tune in for Steph Curry, who plays unlike anyone ever has: The point guard can and might well score at any moment, so he is riveting to watch at every moment.</p>

<p>The EU&rsquo;s deal on migrants and refugees with Turkey is on the verge of collapse as each side is holding firm on its view of Ankara&rsquo;s anti-terrorism legislation.</p>

<p>Under the deal, which went into effect in March, the EU would send those migrants and refugees who illegally entered the bloc to Turkey in exchange for an equal number of registered Syrian refugees. In return, among other things, the EU agreed to visa-free travel for Turks in the Schengen zone provided Ankara satisfied 72 conditions. One of those conditions was altering Turkey&rsquo;s anti-terrorism legislation, which the EU worries could be used to target dissidents as well as journalists. Turkey had, in principle, agreed to tweak the legislation, but Ahmet Davutoglu, the Turkish prime minister who was one of the architects of the agreement with the EU, stepped down earlier this month following a power struggle with Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the country&rsquo;s president. Erdogan has refused to change the law, saying it would embolden terrorists, including ISIS and Kurdish separatists. &ldquo;We are going our way,&rdquo; he said last week to the EU, &ldquo;and you can go yours.&rdquo;</p>

<p>On Thursday in Ankara, Erdogan said the EU was moving the goal posts.</p>

<p>&ldquo;Either we will improve our relations with the EU, or we will set a new path for ourselves,&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;We prefer to build the new Turkey with our EU friends, but now we will wait for the decision of our EU friends.&rdquo;</p>

<p>In Berlin, Jean-Claude Juncker, the European Commission&rsquo;s president, responded: &ldquo;We put great value in the conditions being met. Otherwise this deal, the agreement between the EU and Turkey, won&#39;t happen. If Mr Erdogan decides to deny Turks the right to free travel to Europe, then he must explain this to the Turkish people. It will not be my problem, it will be his problem.&rdquo;</p>

<p>The German government, which worked with Turkey closely on the migrant deal, also stood with the EU. Frank-Walter Steinmeier, the foreign minister, said: &ldquo;<span style="line-height: 1.66667;">The ball is in Turkey&rsquo;s court.&rdquo;</span></p>

<p>The collapse of the agreement has implications far beyond visa-free travel for Turks. The deal was struck in the first place because of Europe&rsquo;s inability to deal with the massive flow of migrants and refugees from Syria and elsewhere. Presumably, that flow of migrants to the EU will pick up once more. Additionally, Turkey has <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/eu-membership-strategic-goal-turkey-erdogan-38982701">long aspired</a> to join the EU; the death of the deal could have consequences for those aspirations, as well.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>For decades, a few antiquated bon mots about the vice presidency have held sway in discussions about running mates. For example, there&rsquo;s Teddy Roosevelt&rsquo;s declaration, &ldquo;I would a great deal rather be anything, say professor of history, than vice president.&rdquo; Even better was John Nance Garner&rsquo;s verdict that the office he held under FDR was &ldquo;not worth a bucket of warm piss.&rdquo; Those quips really hardly apply anymore; they&rsquo;re as archaic as their authors. These days the Naval Observatory is a nice place to land. You could end up amassing unprecedented power and a man-sized safe, like Dick Cheney. You could end up with impressive power and<em> </em>become an aviator-clad folk hero, like Joe Biden.</p>

<p>Or maybe not. Will anyone want to be the running mate to presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump? There are the character risks in cozying up to a man who&rsquo;s liable to make a racist comment or accuse a rival&rsquo;s father of being involved in the Kennedy assassination. There are the career risks of becoming associated with a man who much of the Republican Party still doesn&rsquo;t like. And there are the organizational risks to signing on as No. 2 to a man who&rsquo;s famously a go-it-alone maverick.</p>
