<aside class="callout">
<hr />
<h4>Related Story</h4>

<div><a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/05/where-republicans-stand-on-donald-trump-a-cheat-sheet/481449/"><img alt="" src="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2016/05/RTX1W8YV/lead_960.jpg?1462484933" width="242" /> </a></div>

<p><a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/05/where-republicans-stand-on-donald-trump-a-cheat-sheet/481449/">Where Republicans Stand on Donald Trump: A Cheat Sheet </a></p>

<hr /></aside>
<!-- END "MORE ON" SINGLE STORY BOX v. 2 -->

<p>Will serious policymakers really risk all that? Ha! Of course they will. <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/01/us/politics/donald-trump-vice-president.html">Plenty of major figures have said no</a>, but plenty remain open to it. As another politician of yore, Sam Rayburn, pointed out, &ldquo;Well, there is always the thought in a fellow&#39;s mind that he might get to be president.&rdquo; At this stage in the campaign, it&rsquo;s still customary for possible picks to insist they&rsquo;re not interested. Don&rsquo;t believe it quite yet.</p>

<p>Just who Trump might choose, though, is a different matter. He <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/04/politics/donald-trump-vice-president-search/">has said</a> he&rsquo;ll pick a politician to balance his own outsider status. Trump has also said that Ben Carson, his former rival, will help lead up the process to pick a running mate. Things didn&rsquo;t get off to a great start. Carson <a href="http://www.wsj.com/articles/ben-carson-says-donald-trump-could-consider-democrat-for-running-mate-1462483601">told </a><em><a href="http://www.wsj.com/articles/ben-carson-says-donald-trump-could-consider-democrat-for-running-mate-1462483601">The Wall Street Journal</a> </em>that Trump might consider an independent or a Democrat; Trump promptly said he&rsquo;d only pick a Republican. As the <em>Journal </em>notes, the convention delegates will also have to ratify Trump&rsquo;s choice, adding intrigue.</p>

<p>Who&rsquo;s on the list? Here&rsquo;s a cheat sheet of some of the names being floated&mdash;either by Trump and his aides; or by the candidates or their supporters themselves; or perhaps just being murmured by what Russell Baker memorably called &ldquo;the Great Mentioner.&rdquo; Forecasting who a presidential nominee will pick as a running mate is a famously foolish errand, but we&rsquo;ll keep this list updated as the situation develops, right up to Trump&rsquo;s announcement, which <a href="http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/278910-trump-ill-announce-vp-pick-at-convention">he says will come</a> at the Republican National Convention in July.</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="175" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/Newt_Gingrich_by_Gage_Skidmore_7/2be81353d.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Gage Skidmore</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Newt Gingrich</h3>

<p><strong>Who is he?</strong> The speaker of the House from 1995 to 1999, Gingrich ran unsuccessfully for president in 2012.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt:</strong> Gingrich is <a href="http://www.nationalreview.com/article/434897/newt-gingrich-donald-trump-vice-president-nominee">perhaps the leading contender in Beltway buzz</a>. Though he didn&rsquo;t endorse Trump during the primary, he repeatedly defended him from his critics. More recently, he wrote a fawning essay titled &ldquo;<a href="http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/may/5/newt-gingrich-what-they-never-understood-about-don/">What they never understood about Donald Trump</a>&rdquo; in <em>The Washington Times</em>.</p>

<p><strong>Pros: </strong>With his long career on the Hill and in Republican circles, Gingrich would check the politics box for Trump. As an intellectual&mdash;self-styled, at least&mdash;he might offer some counterweight to impressions of Trump as a lightweight. Gingrich, unlike Roosevelt, would apparently rather be vice president than a professor of history.</p>

<p><strong>Cons:</strong> While less prone than Trump to racist outbursts, Gingrich has been known to <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/newt-gingrich-mulls-vp-nod-world-ideas/story?id=38928856">say wacky things</a>. He has plenty of his own critics in GOP circles, and he&rsquo;s got his own personal baggage&mdash;two divorces and three marriages to match Trump&rsquo;s. As an aging white man, it&rsquo;s unclear whether he could expand the Trump coalition. He brings little foreign-policy cred.</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="171" src="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2015/01/Ben_Carson_by_Gage_Skidmore_2/86c393cf1.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Gage Skidmore</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Ben Carson</h3>

<p><strong>Who is he? </strong>The famed retired neurosurgeon was one of the many GOP candidates Trump vanquished this year.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt:</strong> Wait, isn&rsquo;t he leading the VP search? That&rsquo;s hardly an impediment&mdash;just ask Dick Cheney, who led George W. Bush&rsquo;s running mate search and selected himself. Carson has generally said he&rsquo;s not interested, but that hasn&rsquo;t dampened speculation.</p>

<p><strong>Pros:</strong> Carson is personally likable and well-liked, and he could appeal to social conservatives.</p>

<p><strong>Cons: </strong>Didn&rsquo;t you see the GOP primary? Where Trump is untutored and sometimes scary on policy, Carson is even less tutored, and often shaky. Given his lack if politics and policy experience, he&rsquo;d do little to shore up Trump&rsquo;s credentials with people who view Trump as dangerously naive about policy.</p>

<hr />
<h3>Chris Christie</h3>

<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="170" src="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2015/01/Chris_Christie_2011_Shankbone/8930a1bf5.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">David Shankbone</figcaption>
</figure>

<p><strong>Who is he?</strong> The governor of New Jersey, Christie was the first major establishment Republican to endorse Trump.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt: </strong>Surely there must be some reason why Christie has been willing to endure endless mockery for standing, staring vacantly, behind Trump at campaign events. Could it be the promise of a VP slot?</p>

<p><strong>Pros:</strong> Christie would bring comparative gravitas to the ticket. He&rsquo;s a two-term governor and former U.S. attorney, a dynamic campaigner, and he seems to get along well with Trump. He&rsquo;s <a href="https://twitter.com/sarahmccammon/status/729688535976976384">already been appointed to run Trump&rsquo;s transition team</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Cons:</strong> Just what the ticket needs: Another angry dude from the Northeast with high unfavorables. Christie infuriated many fellow Republicans by backing Trump, but <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/05/where-republicans-stand-on-donald-trump-a-cheat-sheet/481449/">now that many of them are coming around</a>, perhaps that&rsquo;s not a big deal.</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="175" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/Bob_Corker_official_Senate_photo/8188ab05a.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Wikimedia</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Bob Corker</h3>

<p><strong>Who is he?</strong> A Tennessee Republican, he was first elected to the Senate in 2007.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt: </strong>Mike Allen <a href="http://www.politico.com/playbook/2016/05/the-1-official-who-most-closely-fits-trumps-description-of-ideal-vp-trump-hillary-tied-in-fla-penn-bdays-andy-card-gabe-debenedetti-craig-gordon-stan-greenberg-mel-sembler-214204">argues</a> that Corker most perfectly fits Trump&rsquo;s stated qualifications for a vice-presidential ticketmate. Corker has also been <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/05/06/sen-bob-corker-says-hell-advise-donald-trump-foreign-policy/84016332/">chatting</a> with Trump about foreign policy. Corker&rsquo;s office <a href="http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/politics/2016/05/10/bob-corker-dismisses-donald-trump-running-mate-theory/84179096/">says</a> he &ldquo;has no reason to believe he is being considered for vice president.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Pros: </strong>Corker is a businessman like Trump, and he&rsquo;s a known as a dealmaker. He&rsquo;d bring some Southern balance to the ticket, and he is the chair of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and a member of the banking committee&mdash;and both foreign policy and economic policy are areas where Trump has shown he needs some help. Corker signaled his openness to Trump ahead of many of his colleagues.</p>

<p><strong>Cons:</strong> The flip side of being a dealmaker is that fellow Republicans don&rsquo;t love Corker. He&rsquo;s also a bit low-key for Trump&mdash;though maybe that would be a good thing.</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="175" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/Mike_Pence_official_portrait_112th_Congress/49c932f1e.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Wikimedia</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3><strong>Mike Pence</strong></h3>

<p><strong>Who is he? </strong>A former U.S. representative, the current Indiana governor is a strong social conservative.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt:</strong> Mike Allen <a href="http://www.politico.com/playbook/2016/05/the-1-official-who-most-closely-fits-trumps-description-of-ideal-vp-trump-hillary-tied-in-fla-penn-bdays-andy-card-gabe-debenedetti-craig-gordon-stan-greenberg-mel-sembler-214204">reports</a> that Pence is in at least the early stages of vetting. Pence endorsed Trump a couple days after Trump won the Indiana primary.</p>

<p><strong>Pros: </strong>Pence is a strong social conservative and a longtime Republican officeholder&mdash;two areas where Trump is weak. He&rsquo;s also close to the Koch brothers.</p>

<p><strong>Cons:</strong> Once mentioned as a presidential contender in his own right, Pence has looked a little like damaged good since Indiana&rsquo;s snafu over a religious-freedom law. (A law was passed but largely emptied out by amendments after backlash.) Pence also endorse Ted Cruz in the Hoosier State primary&mdash;though he was careful to cast his remarks in general terms and not to condemn Trump at the time.</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="169" src="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2015/01/Sarah_Palin_September_4_2014_cropped/52935af4b.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Gage Skidmore</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Sarah Palin</h3>

<p><strong>Who is she?</strong> The former governor of Alaska endorsed Trump in January. She was John McCain&rsquo;s running mate in 2008.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt:</strong> Palin is a high-profile endorser and has been an ambitious politician in the past. When Trump was asked about the prospect of running with her in January, he <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/01/20/politics/donald-trump-sarah-palin-vice-president/">said</a>: &quot;I don&#39;t think she&#39;d want to do it &hellip; she&rsquo;s been through that.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Pros: </strong>Trump is weak with women and still stands to convince very conservative voters that he is a true conservative. Palin might help him on both counts.</p>

<p><strong>Cons:</strong> Are you younger than eight? (If so, go outside and play!) If not, did you sleep through the 2008 election? We&rsquo;ve seen how this goes.</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="John Kasich" height="179" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2015/05/kasich/c5092995c.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Wikimedia</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>John Kasich</h3>

<p><strong>Who is he? </strong>The governor of Ohio, Kasich was the last remaining Republican to leave the race.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt:</strong> Kasich&rsquo;s critics in the party <a href="http://www.msnbc.com/hardball/watch/is-kasich-really-running-for-a-trump-vp-spot-662083139526">accused</a> him of staying in the race to hurt Cruz, and thus improve his chances at the VP slot. Trump has sent mixed messages, saying that he&rsquo;d be &ldquo;<a href="http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/278704-trump-interested-in-vetting-kasich-for-vp">interested in vetting John</a>&rdquo; but also <a href="http://www.cnbc.com/2016/05/05/trump-kasich-unlikely-to-be-my-running-mate-choice.html">suggesting</a> he was an unlikely choice.</p>

<p><strong>Pros:</strong> Kasich has deep political experience, as both a congressman and a two-term governor. And he cuts a more sober figure than Trump.</p>

<p><strong>Cons:</strong> Kasich&rsquo;s presidential campaign weighs against him. On the one hand, it showed he has limited appeal. On the other, he spent most of it calling for sanity and reason in the race&mdash;basically, everything Trump doesn&rsquo;t stand for. Bloomberg reports that Trump&rsquo;s camp is still courting Kasich, but he <a href="http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-05-10/kasich-remains-cool-to-prospect-of-joining-trump-ticket">remains aloof to their pleas</a>.</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="170" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2015/05/63682c308/47b13d86b.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Wikimedia</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3><strong>Marco Rubio</strong></h3>

<p><strong>Who is he? </strong>The outgoing senator from Florida also ran against Trump.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt:</strong> <a href="http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/278847-former-rubio-delegates-push-senator-for-donald-trumps-vp">Some of Rubio&rsquo;s delegates</a> to the convention are pushing him as a running mate. Trump says it &ldquo;<a href="http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/278938-trump-rubio-as-vp-could-happen">could happen</a>,&rdquo; though other reports <a href="http://www.newsmax.com/Newsfront/ben-carson-trump-vp/2016/05/05/id/727426/">claim</a> he&rsquo;s out of the running. Also Rubio has <a href="http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/the-buzz-florida-politics/rubio-as-trumps-vp-some-can-dream/2275866">said</a>, &ldquo;I&rsquo;m not going to be anybody&rsquo;s vice president.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Pros:</strong> All the things that Rubio was supposed to bring to the presidential race, he could still bring: youth. Charisma. Hispanic roots and foreign-policy experience, both of which Trump badly needs.</p>

<p><strong>Cons: </strong>Rubio hit Trump hard during the race, and he seems to be pretty burnt out on campaigning and politics in general. On May 9, he <a href="https://www.facebook.com/MarcoRubio/posts/10154177059937708">posted on Facebook</a>, &ldquo;He will be best served by a running mate and by surrogates who fully embrace his campaign. As such, I have never sought, will not seek and do not want to be considered for Vice President.&rdquo;</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="170" src="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2015/01/Rick_Perry_by_Gage_Skidmore_8/640fb9f04.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Gage Skidmore</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Rick Perry</h3>

<p><strong>Who is he? </strong>The former governor of Texas ran for president unsuccessfully in 2012 and 2016.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt: </strong>On May 5, <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/05/politics/rick-perry-endorses-donald-trump/index.html">Perry told CNN</a>, &ldquo;I believe in the process, and the process has said Donald Trump will be our nominee and I&#39;m going to support him and help him and do what I can &hellip;. He is one of the most talented people who has ever run for the president I have ever seen.&rdquo; On the veep question, he said, &ldquo;I am going to be open to any way I can help. I am not going to say no.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Pros:</strong> Perry doesn&rsquo;t exactly have a reputation as a policy whiz, though he tried to reverse that in his second go at the presidency. He&rsquo;s a steady, experienced Republican, and his Texas bravado might pair well with Trump&rsquo;s New York braggadocio.</p>

<p><strong>Cons: </strong>&ldquo;He offers a barking carnival act that can be best described as Trumpism: a toxic mix of demagoguery, mean-spiritedness and nonsense that will lead the Republican Party to perdition if pursued. Let no one be mistaken&mdash;Donald Trump&rsquo;s candidacy is a cancer on conservatism, and it must be clearly diagnosed, excised, and discarded.&rdquo; &mdash;<a href="https://rickperry.org/defending-conservatism-against-the-cancer-of-trump-ism">Perry on July 22, 2015</a></p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="170" src="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2015/01/Ted_Cruz_official_portrait_113th_Congress/5640b30ae.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Wikimedia</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Ted Cruz</h3>

<p><strong>Who is he? </strong>Trump&rsquo;s final serious rival for the nomination, he&rsquo;s a senator from Texas.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt: </strong>Trump <a href="http://www.redstate.com/brandon_morse/2016/05/05/trump-open-cruz-vp/">said on May 4</a> that he&rsquo;d consider Cruz.</p>

<p><strong>Pros: </strong>Trump says he wants to unify the party, and since the final split was ultimately between Cruz and Trump, what better way to bring together two factions than in a classic fusion ticket? Cruz would bring his very conservative bonafides to the ticket.</p>

<p><strong>Cons: </strong>Many leading Republicans hate Cruz as much or more than they do Trump. Also, while the two men got along well early in the campaign, Cruz unloaded on Trump&mdash;understandably&mdash;after Trump suggested Cruz&rsquo;s father was involved in the JFK assassination, calling him a &ldquo;pathological liar,&rdquo; &ldquo;utterly amoral,&rdquo; a &ldquo;narcissist,&rdquo; and &ldquo;serial philanderer.&rdquo;</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="175" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/Rick_Scott_cropped/aee686a35.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Wikimedia</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Rick Scott</h3>

<p><strong>Who is he? </strong>Florida&rsquo;s governor, Scott is a former health-care executive.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt:</strong> Scott endorsed Trump on March 15. He&rsquo;s suggested he&rsquo;s not interested in the gig. &ldquo;I like my job. I worked hard to get this job. I&rsquo;m going to stay in this job,&rdquo; <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/rick-scott-donald-trump-veep-222828">he told CNN</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Pros: </strong>He&rsquo;s a two-term governor, and Florida is an important swing state</p>

<p><strong>Cons:</strong> Scott is deeply unpopular in his own state, and he carries lots of baggage&mdash;particularly a $1.7 billion fine for Medicare fraud levied on the company he ran.</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="175" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/Rob_Portman_official_portrait_112th_Congress/95a6ff36b.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Wikimedia</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Rob Portman</h3>

<p><strong>Who is he? </strong>Portman is a senator from Ohio.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt:</strong> Trump&rsquo;s campaign has <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/04/politics/donald-trump-vice-president-search/">leaked his name as an early favorite</a>. A spokesman <a href="http://www.politico.com/blogs/2016-gop-primary-live-updates-and-results/2016/05/rob-portman-no-trump-vice-president-222848">said Portman is not interested</a>: &ldquo;Rob is not interested in anything but continuing to serve Ohio in the U.S. Senate.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Pros:</strong> Portman is well-liked and has a reputation for seriousness. He might help Trump in the crucial swing state of Ohio and across the Midwest. Barry Bennett, a longtime Portman aide, is now a top aide to Trump.</p>

<p><strong>Cons: </strong>Portman is in the middle of a heated Senate campaign. He&rsquo;d probably be unable to run for president and run for Senate effectively without risking handing the seat to Democrat Ted Strickland.</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="175" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/Official_Photo_of_SC_Governor_Nikki_Haley/1318b8fdc.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Wikimedia</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Nikki Haley</h3>

<p><strong>Who is she? </strong>Haley is the governor of South Carolina.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt: </strong>Trump&rsquo;s campaign has <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/04/politics/donald-trump-vice-president-search/">named her</a> as a top early pick, but Trump himself <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/05/05/trump-nikki-haley-vice-president/83980310/">said</a>, &ldquo;No, not Nikki Haley, no Nikki Haley no, she wasn&rsquo;t under consideration.&rdquo; She herself <a href="http://www.politico.com/blogs/2016-gop-primary-live-updates-and-results/2016/05/nikki-haley-donald-trump-222819">said</a>, &ldquo;My plate is full and I am not interested in serving as vice president.&quot;</p>

<p><strong>Pros:</strong> Not only is Haley a veteran governor, but as a woman, a Southerner, and a daughter of immigrants, Haley would plug lots of holes for Trump. She won positive national press by backing the push to take down the Confederate flag from the capitol grounds in Columbia.</p>

<p><strong>Cons:</strong> Haley and Trump tangled ahead of the South Carolina primary, which Haley ultimately <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/01/politics/nikki-haley-donald-trump-bless-your-heart/">deploying the ultimate, vicious Southern insult on Trump</a>: &ldquo;Bless your heart.&rdquo;</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="175" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/Governor_NewMexico/3994cb1c8.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Wikimedia</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Susana Martinez</h3>

<p><strong>Who is she?</strong> The governor of New Mexico, Martinez is a perennial long-list candidate for the vice presidency.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt: </strong>She&rsquo;s another one of the <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/04/politics/donald-trump-vice-president-search/">early favorites leaked by the Trump campaign</a>. &ldquo;The governor has said repeatedly over the years that she isn&rsquo;t interested in serving as Vice President,&rdquo; her spokesman <a href="http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/278887-nm-gov-not-interested-in-being-trumps-running-mate">replied</a>. &ldquo;She appreciates that such attention puts New Mexico in the spotlight, but she is fully committed to serving the people of our state.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Pros: </strong>In addition to her experience as governor, Martinez is a woman and a Hispanic, both constituencies with which Trump is very weak.</p>

<p><strong>Cons: </strong>Martinez has been <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/04/19/new-mexico-gov-susana-martinez-makes-sharp-critique-of-trump-at-rga-donor-event/">harshly critical</a> of Trump. She also <a href="http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/new-mexico-gov-apologizes-staff-conduct-hotel-party-article-1.2471226">brings some personal baggage</a>.</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="175" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/Brian_Sandoval_2010/987a4e40b.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Wikimedia</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Brian Sandoval</h3>

<p><strong>Who is he?</strong> Sandoval is the governor of Nevada, a moderate Republican and another perennial VP possibility.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt:</strong> Remember when this guy was floated as an Obama Supreme Court nominee? Good times. Sandoval&rsquo;s name seems to mostly be in the mix because it always is. <a href="http://www.nbcnews.com/news/latino/nevada-gov-brian-sandoval-says-he-will-now-support-trump-n568796">He endorsed Trump on May 5</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Pros: </strong>Sandoval is an experienced politician and a popular Hispanic elected official. He could potentially help Trump with Hispanics and in the West.</p>

<p><strong>Cons: </strong>Sandoval has sometimes been seen as too moderate for a national GOP ticket. He also says he <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/09/us/politics/donald-trumps-warning-to-paul-ryan-signals-further-gop-discord.html?em_pos=large&amp;emc=edit_nn_20160509&amp;nl=morning-briefing&amp;nlid=12975946&amp;ref=todayspaper&amp;_r=1">doesn&rsquo;t plan to attend the convention</a>.</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="175" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/AP_163836744340/a6074a476.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Evan Agostini / Invision / AP</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Joe Scarborough</h3>

<p><strong>Who is he? </strong>The co-host of MSNBC&rsquo;s <em>Morning Joe</em>, Scarborough previously served as a congressman from Florida.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt:</strong> Scarborough has been one of Trump&rsquo;s biggest cheerleaders in the mainstream media. When Hugh Hewitt asked him if in January he&rsquo;d serve as Trump&rsquo;s VP, Scarborough <a href="http://mediamatters.org/video/2016/01/27/on-the-hugh-hewitt-show-msnbcs-joe-scarborough/208227">couldn&rsquo;t bring himself to say no</a>. He&rsquo;s clearly thirsty to get back into politics&mdash;he even <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2014/03/joe-scarborough-for-president-sure-why-not/284443/">flirted with running for president in 2016</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Pros: </strong>Scarborough has media savvy and has had a great rapport with Trump. He&rsquo;s not a professional politician these days, but he&rsquo;s got the resume.</p>

<p><strong>Cons: </strong>Precisely which GOP voters would line up to back a Beltway-dwelling, moderate Republican MSNBC host? Meanwhile, Scarborough has complained that Trump was <a href="http://www.mediaite.com/online/joe-scarborough-says-he-wont-vote-for-trump-unless-he-changes-his-tune/">genuine rather than simply pandering</a> in his fearmongering on Muslims, and Trump <a href="https://twitter.com/realdonaldtrump/status/728651908563517440">fired back at him</a>.</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="175" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/8223917995_889d60d208_o/dadf16032.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Michael Vadon / Flickr</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Mary Fallin</h3>

<p><strong>Who is she?</strong> Fallin is the second-term governor of Oklahoma.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt:</strong> Trump backer of Andre Bauer of South Carolina floated her name in April; Trump <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/24/politics/mary-fallin-donald-trump-vice-president/">responded</a> that it was &ldquo;great&rdquo; advice. She <a href="http://www.koco.com/news/gov-mary-fallin-endorses-trumps-presidential-bid-welcomes-vp-talk/39378324">says</a> she is &ldquo;100 percent behind him&rdquo; and said in a <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/04/politics/donald-trump-vice-president-search/">statement</a>, &ldquo;I have not had any direct contact with Mr. Trump, but I would be very honored if I were to receive a call saying I need you to help make America great again.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Pros:</strong> Fallin is an experienced governor and a woman. Former Arizona Governor Jan Brewer has reportedly <a href="http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/05/11/donald-trump-jan-brewer-vice-president/84262682/">recommended</a> her.</p>

<p><strong>Cons: </strong>She&rsquo;s not much of a proven quantity or familiar face at a national level.</p>

<hr />
<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="175" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/Jan_Brewer_by_Gage_Skidmore_3/a6cad1001.jpg" width="150" />
<figcaption class="credit">Gage Skidmore</figcaption>
</figure>

<h3>Jan Brewer</h3>

<p><strong>Who is she?</strong> Brewer was governor of Arizona from 2009 to 2015.</p>

<p><strong>The scuttlebutt:</strong> Brewer has reportedly recommended Mary Fallin of Oklahoma for the veep job. Asked about that, Trump told Greta Van Susteren, &ldquo;Well, also Jan. Jan Brewer has been fantastic. She has been so fantastic. You know I won so big, her territory, and we won so big. And she is a fabulous woman.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Pros: </strong>Brewer is a woman and a conservative, and her hardline views on immigration dovetail well with Trump&rsquo;s. Arizona is one of the typically Republican states that Democrats believe could be up for grabs with Trump running, and she&rsquo;d help shore that up.</p>

<p><strong>Cons:</strong> Brewer is unproven at a national level, and some of her performance in Arizona is unpromising. She famously made an unsupported claim about &ldquo;headless bodies&rdquo; being found in the desert, and <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kLXxONrXCjE">her disastrous opening statement in a 2010 gubernatorial debate</a> recalled nothing so much as another vice-presidential candidate&mdash;<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T1w3FgB0Ohc">Admiral James Stockdale</a>.</p>

<p>How do you solve a problem like The Donald? For Republicans and conservatives, the time for hoping Trump would simply burn himself out, collapse, and go away is over. With the exits of Ted Cruz and John Kasich, the entertainer is now the presumptive GOP nominee.</p>

<p>That poses a dilemma for the Republican official or conservative opinionmaker who doesn&rsquo;t like Trump, disagrees with his policies, and/or thinks he will harm GOP and the conservative movement. Swallow hard and back Trump? Try to coalesce around a third-party candidate? Sit out the election and risk allowing Hillary Clinton to win the presidency, or even back her rather than risk letting Trump win?</p>

<p>As the chaotic and failed attempts to stop Trump over the 10 months have shown, there&rsquo;s no obviously right choice. But which choice are people making? Here&rsquo;s a list of some major figures and where they stand on Trump&mdash;right now. We&rsquo;ll keep it updated as other important people take stances, or as these ones change their views about Trump.</p>

<hr />
<h3>Party Elders</h3>

<figure><img alt="" height="432" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/RTXYZYB/7e3c49df4.jpg" width="630" />
<figcaption class="credit">Jason Reed/ Reuters</figcaption>
</figure>

<p><strong>George W. Bush: ABSTAIN</strong><br />
The former president &ldquo;does not plan to participate in or comment on the presidential campaign,&rdquo; <a href="https://www.texastribune.org/2016/05/04/bush-41-43-have-no-plans-endorse-trump/">an aide told the <em>Texas Tribune</em></a>. (May 4, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>George H.W. Bush: ABSTAIN</strong><br />
&ldquo;At age 91, President Bush is retired from politics. He came out of retirement to do a few things for Jeb, but those were the exceptions that proved the rule,&rdquo; <a href="https://www.texastribune.org/2016/05/04/bush-41-43-have-no-plans-endorse-trump/">an aide told the <em>Texas Tribune</em></a>. (May 4, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Mitt Romney: NAY</strong><br />
The party&rsquo;s 2012 nominee&mdash;and one of Trump&rsquo;s staunchest critics during the primary&mdash;<a href="https://www.texastribune.org/2016/05/04/bush-41-43-have-no-plans-endorse-trump/">told </a><em><a href="https://www.texastribune.org/2016/05/04/bush-41-43-have-no-plans-endorse-trump/">The Washington Post</a> </em>he would skip the Republican National Convention in Cleveland, and <a href="http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/article/2590558/">said</a> at a D.C. dinner that he won&rsquo;t be supporting Trump. (May 5, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Bob Dole: YEA</strong><br />
The former Senate majority leader and 1996 GOP presidential nominee <a href="http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/former-gop-nominee-bob-dole-endorses-donald-trump-n569716">endorsed Trump on May 6</a>. He <a href="https://twitter.com/Bencjacobs/status/728261147707752448">will also be the only living GOP nominee to attend the RNC</a>. (May 6, 2016.) Dole previously <a href="https://twitter.com/Bencjacobs/status/728262449250578433">would not commit to voting for Trump</a> but <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2016/01/20/bob-dole-warns-of-cataclysmic-losses-with-ted-cruz-and-says-donald-trump-would-do-better/">said in January</a> that Trump would be preferable to Cruz. (May 5, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>John Boehner: YEA</strong><br />
The former speaker, who says he and Trump are &ldquo;texting buddies,&rdquo; <a href="http://www.stanforddaily.com/2016/04/28/john-boehner-talks-election-time-in-office/">told an audience at Stanford University</a> that he&rsquo;d back Trump in the general election. (April 28, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Trent Lott: YEA</strong><br />
The former Senate majority leader <a href="http://www.clarionledger.com/story/news/2016/05/04/trent-lott-speaks-about-broken-politics/83833192/">told </a><em><a href="http://www.clarionledger.com/story/news/2016/05/04/trent-lott-speaks-about-broken-politics/83833192/">The Clarion-Ledger</a> </em>that he will back Trump, despite some reservations. (May 4, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Tom DeLay: UNDECIDED</strong><br />
The former House majority leader hasn&rsquo;t spoken out since Trump&rsquo;s ascension, but was highly critical of him during the primary: &ldquo;We have got to stop Trump. Whatever it takes without cheating or violating the rules of the Republican primaries,&rdquo; <a href="http://www.newsmax.com/Newsmax-Tv/tom-delay-republicans-stop-donald-trump/2016/03/09/id/718324/">he told <em>Newsmax</em></a>.</p>

<p><strong>Dick Cheney: YEA</strong><br />
The former vice president blasted Trump during the primary over his stance on 9/11, and said he &ldquo;<a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/02/dick-cheney-trump-219313">sounds like a liberal Democrat</a>,&rdquo; but he now <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/06/politics/dick-cheney-donald-trump/index.html">says he will back the nominee</a>. (May 6, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Newt Gingrich: YEA</strong><br />
The former speaker of the House did not formally endorse Trump during the primary, but he has <a href="http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/interrogation/2016/03/newt_gingrich_discusses_the_merits_of_donald_trump.html">repeatedly praised the mogul and his vision</a>, and is said to be a contender for a position in a Trump administration.</p>

<p><strong>Jeb Bush: NAY</strong><br />
The former Florida governor and presidential candidate came to detest Trump during the campaign. <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/12/politics/republican-convention-2016/index.html">In April</a>, he said he would not attend the Republican National Convention. He <a href="https://www.facebook.com/jebbush/posts/876702172458827">now says</a> he will not vote for either Trump or Clinton. (May 6, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Reince Priebus: YEA</strong><br />
As chair of the Republican National Committee, Priebus doesn&#39;t really have a choice, though that doesn&rsquo;t mean he <a href="http://talkingpointsmemo.com/livewire/reince-priebus-baileys-cereal-johnnie-walker">won&rsquo;t pour Baileys in his cereal over it</a>. (May 4, 2016)</p>

<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p dir="ltr" lang="en">.<a href="https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump">@realDonaldTrump</a> will be presumptive <a href="https://twitter.com/GOP">@GOP</a> nominee, we all need to unite and focus on defeating <a href="https://twitter.com/HillaryClinton">@HillaryClinton</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/NeverClinton?src=hash">#NeverClinton</a></p>
&mdash; Reince Priebus (@Reince) <a href="https://twitter.com/Reince/status/727665447684820992">May 4, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>

<p>Priebus <a href="http://fortune.com/2016/05/06/donald-trump-must-change-his-tone-gop-chairman-says/">said on May 6</a> that Trump needs to change his tone.</p>

<p><strong>Rick Perry: YEA</strong><br />
The former Texas governor and presidential candidate&mdash;<a href="https://rickperry.org/defending-conservatism-against-the-cancer-of-trump-ism">who was one of the first to blast Trump</a>&mdash;<a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/rick-perry-donald-trump-vice-president-vp-222877#ixzz47pZSJgiO">told CNN that he backs Trump</a>. (5/5/16)</p>

<p><strong>Mike Huckabee: YEA</strong><br />
The former Arkansas governor, who ran for president this year, says Republicans should get in line. &nbsp;&ldquo;When we nominated people over the past several election cycles, some of us had heartburn, but we stepped up and supported the nominee,&rdquo; <a href="http://www.mediaite.com/online/huckabee-rips-nevertrump-if-youre-not-going-to-support-voters-choice-leave-the-gop/">he said</a>. &ldquo;You&rsquo;re either on the team, or you&rsquo;re not on the team.&rdquo; (May 5, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Bobby Jindal: YEA</strong><br />
The former Louisiana governor, who during his own presidential campaign <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2015/09/11/a-week-of-insults-as-candidates-turn-nasty-and-personal/">called Trump</a> a &ldquo;narcissist&rdquo; and an &ldquo;egomaniacal madman,&rdquo; wrote in a <i>Wall Street Journal </i><a href="http://www.wsj.com/articles/im-voting-trump-warts-and-all-1462739009">column</a> that he&rsquo;s voting for Trump, &ldquo;warts and all.&rdquo; &ldquo;I think electing Donald Trump would be the second-worst thing we could do this November, better only than electing Hillary Clinton to serve as the third term for the Obama administration&rsquo;s radical policies,&rdquo; he said. (May 9, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Eric Cantor: YEA</strong><br />
Cantor, the former U.S. representative from Virginia and House majority leader, says he will back Trump, though <a href="http://www.bostonglobe.com/news/politics/2016/05/08/wall-street-befuddled-alarmed-donald-trump-and-may-turn-democratic-ticket/T1o4HZYA8pryPuMmxz71xJ/story.html">he offered a tepid endorsement</a>, saying a Trump-Clinton matchup was &ldquo;probably not the best choice for anybody,&rdquo; and adding, &ldquo;He&rsquo;s a businessman . . . [but] he&rsquo;s been on so many sides of every issue that you never know.&rdquo; (May 9, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Ben Carson: YEA</strong><br />
Carson, a relative political newcomer who ran for president in 2016, has become one of Trump&rsquo;s most prominent surrogates, despite repeatedly voicing misgivings about the candidate.</p>

<hr />
<h3>Representatives</h3>

<figure><img alt="" height="420" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/RTX2B22L/bb46508d7.jpg" width="630" />
<figcaption class="credit">Jonathan Ernst / Reuters</figcaption>
</figure>

<p><strong>Paul Ryan: UNDECIDED</strong><br />
The House speaker has said in the past he intended to support the Republican nominee, but he now says he&rsquo;s not prepared to back Trump&mdash;yet. &ldquo;To be perfectly candid with you, I&rsquo;m just not ready to that at this point,&rdquo; he told CNN&rsquo;s Jake Tapper. &ldquo;I&rsquo;m not there. I hope to, and I want to.&rdquo; He said the party needs &ldquo;a standard-bearer that bears our standards.&rdquo; (May 5, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Kevin McCarthy: YEA</strong><br />
The House majority leader, a Californian, has broken with Speaker Paul Ryan and will back Trump. McCarthy <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/kevin-mccarthy-donald-trump-222998">has signed up as a prospective delegate</a> for Trump in the Golden State. (May 10, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Steve Scalise: YEA</strong><br />
The House majority whip, a Louisiana representative, <a href="http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2016/05/louisiana_gop_gets_behind_trum.html">offered</a> Trump a tepid endorsement. (The two men share the <a href="http://theweek.com/speedreads/440133/steve-scalise-reportedly-said-like-david-duke-without-baggage">dubious distinction</a> of being linked politically to David Duke.) &ldquo;I&#39;ve always said that I will support the Republican nominee,&rdquo; Scalise said. &ldquo;Now is the time for for our party to unite around Donald Trump so that we can focus on defeating Hillary Clinton in November to prevent another four years of job-killing, big government policies so we can get our economy back on track.&rdquo; (May 5, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Cathy McMorris Rodgers: UNDECIDED</strong><br />
The Washington representative, who is chair of the House Republican Caucus, has not made up her mind. &ldquo;Before I endorse him, I would like to have a conversation with him. I would like to ask him questions about some of the statements he&rsquo;s made,&rdquo; <a href="http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2016/may/05/mcmorris-rodgers-hesitant-on-trump-senate-challeng/">she told <em>The Spokesman-Review</em></a>. (May 5, 2016)</p>

<hr />
<h3>Senators</h3>

<figure><img alt="" height="378" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/RTX2APHQ/4e8c37f53.jpg" width="630" />
<figcaption class="credit">Yuri Gripas / Reuters</figcaption>
</figure>

<p><strong>Mitch McConnell: YEA</strong><br />

(May 5, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Joe and Marlene Ricketts: UNDECIDED</strong><br />
The billionaire couple spent at least $5.5 million on anti-Trump efforts during the primary, and Trump at one point <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/02/22/trump-ricketts-family-better-careful/80761060/">threatened</a> them, tweeting, &ldquo;They better be careful, they have a lot to hide!&rdquo; They <a href="http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/large-gop-donors-warming-trump-not-everyone-sold-n568906">have not made their stance public</a>, though their son Pete, the governor of Nebraska, has endorsed Trump.</p>

<p><strong>Charles and David Koch: SOFT NAY</strong><br />
Prior to Trump&rsquo;s becoming the presumptive GOP nominee, Charles Koch said he thought Hillary Clinton might be a better president than Trump, though he made no indication that the famed pair of brothers would back her. <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/trump-megadonors-koch-222825">They now say they are not backing Trump</a>, though a spokesman did not rule it out entirely. (May 5, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Peter Thiel: YEA</strong><br />
Thiel, the PayPal founder and well-known venture capitalist, is known as a libertarian&mdash;though Rand Paul tried and failed to court him as a major backer. (Thiel ended up donating to former Silicon Valley denizen Carly Fiorina.) Thiel has <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/Business/billionaire-paypal-founder-peter-thiel-list-trump-backers/story?id=39006891">signed up as a prospective Trump delegate</a> from California. (May 10, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>Stanley Hubbard: YEA</strong><br />
Hubbard, a longtime Republican donor, <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/04/billionaires-fund-anti-trump-delegate-push-221819">gave thousands to the Stop Trump effort earlier this spring</a>. Now he says he&rsquo;ll back Trump. &ldquo;All of my favorite candidates dropped out one by one,&rdquo; <a href="http://www.politico.com/blogs/2016-gop-primary-live-updates-and-results/2016/05/stanley-hubbard-donald-trump-great-america-pac-222981#ixzz48CHd1GMe">he told <i>Politico</i></a>. &ldquo;We&rsquo;re down to my least favorite candidate. And my least favorite candidate is better than Hillary Clinton in terms of what&rsquo;s best for the country.&rdquo; (May 10, 2016)</p>

<p><strong>T. Boone Pickens: YEA</strong><br />
The Oklahoma oil billionaire&mdash;and recent <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pickens_Plan">renewable-energy fanatic</a>&mdash;is a former Jeb Bush backer, but Pickens now supports Trump, citing his support for Trump&rsquo;s ban on Muslim immigration. &ldquo;Yes, I&rsquo;m for Donald Trump &hellip; I&rsquo;m tired of having politicians as president of the U.S.,&rdquo; <a href="http://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2016/05/11/billionaire-t-boone-pickens-backs-donald-trump-muslim-ban/">he told <em>The Wall Street Journal</em></a>. He will <a href="http://www.wsj.com/articles/billionaire-t-boone-pickens-planning-trump-fundraiser-1463021638">host a fundraiser for a pro-Trump super PAC</a>. (May 12, 2016)</p>

<hr />
<h3>Faith Leaders</h3>

<p><strong>Jerry Falwell Jr.: YEA</strong><br />
Falwell, president of Liberty University and son of the iconic Moral Majority leader, has been one of Trump&rsquo;s staunchest backers.</p>

<p><strong>Russell Moore: NAY</strong><br />
Moore, who is president of the Ethics and Religious Liberty Commission of the Southern Baptist Convention, says he will not vote for either Trump or Clinton but <a href="https://twitter.com/drmoore/status/728368531222478848">will write in Ben Sasse</a>. (May 5, 2016)</p>

<p>An $800 million U.S. missile-defense site became operational Thursday in Romania despite Moscow&rsquo;s assertions that it was a &ldquo;threat to the Russian Federation.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Jens Stoltenberg, NATO&rsquo;s secretary general, said the activation of the site &ldquo;represents a significant increase in the capability to defend European Allies against the proliferation of ballistic missiles from outside the Euro-Atlantic area.&rdquo; He insisted that NATO&rsquo;s ballistic defense was not directed at Russia. Indeed, the U.S. maintains the system is aimed at threats from Iran and North Korea. Moscow, however, was unconvinced.</p>

<p>&ldquo;We have been saying right from when this story started that our experts are convinced that the deployment of the ABM system poses a certain threat to the Russian Federation,&rdquo; <a href="https://www.rt.com/news/342734-us-missiles-romania-russia/">Dmitry Peskov, the presidential spokesman, said</a>.</p>

<p>He added: &ldquo;Measures are being taken to ensure the necessary level of security for Russia.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Millions of iPhone and Android users might get a fright this week, as they glance down at their home screen to ogle their friends&rsquo;s photos. Where before they had tapped on a friendly and venerable cartoon of a camera, now they&rsquo;ll behold a smear of fuchsia and creamsicle and the barest geometric hint at a lens.</p>

<p>Instagram, <a href="http://qz.com/481245/these-are-the-25-most-popular-2015-mobile-apps-in-america/">the tenth-most popular app in the United States</a>, has changed its icon.</p>

<figure><img alt="" height="280" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/instagram_logo/2792c1a8a.gif" width="500" />
<figcaption class="credit">Instagram</figcaption>
</figure>

<p>People rarely respond well to dramatic design changes, and they did not seem to take well to Instagram&rsquo;s. &ldquo;The Great Instagram Logo Freakout of 2016,&rdquo; <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/technology/the-great-instagram-logo-freakout-of-2016.html">huffed </a><em><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/technology/the-great-instagram-logo-freakout-of-2016.html">The New York Times</a>. &ldquo;</em>A travesty,&rdquo; <a href="http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/instagrams-new-logo-travesty-can-we-change-it-back-please-171398">blared </a><em><a href="http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/instagrams-new-logo-travesty-can-we-change-it-back-please-171398">AdWeek</a>. </em>Before the release, <a href="http://www.fastcodesign.com/3059740/an-exclusive-look-at-instagrams-new-app-icon"><em>Fast Company </em>asked Ian Spalter</a>, the app&rsquo;s design director,<em> </em>about what he would do if the launch went poorly. &ldquo;Maybe I&rsquo;ll take a vacation,&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;In a bunker.&rdquo;</p>

<p>He need not go underground yet. I cannot remember a single rebranding that has ever been well received on its first day. (Which is a little odd&mdash;lots of people take interest in design as amateurs, and new icons and major interface changes are the closest thing design has to an album or movie release.) It&rsquo;s a fun and rote exercise, actually, the logo-hype cycle. If you&rsquo;re a journalist, you can announce the new logo, cite all the angry tweets, and allude to how logos have to stand the test of time and how that time is longer than a few hours on Twitter, et cetera.</p>

<p>By the time people have drawn more considered opinions of the new design, folks beyond the professional design community have maybe forgotten that it ever happened. <a href="http://www.underconsideration.com/brandnew/archives/new_icon_for_instagram_done_in_house.php#.VzOssGQrK2w">As Armin Vit says at </a><em><a href="http://www.underconsideration.com/brandnew/archives/new_icon_for_instagram_done_in_house.php#.VzOssGQrK2w">Brand New</a>, </em>200 million people tapping on your logo every day is &ldquo;the kind of brand engagement that Coca-Cola or Nike would kill for.&rdquo;</p>

<p>&ldquo;It will only be a matter of time&mdash; three months, probably&mdash;before this is known, recognized, and considered as <em>the</em> Instagram app icon,&rdquo; he adds.</p>

<p><span style="line-height: 1.66667;">Also, in defense of the cycle, some of the angry tweets are actually pretty funny.</span></p>

<figure>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p dir="ltr" lang="en">Behind the scenes on the new Instagram logo <a href="https://t.co/WPld3t0rJF">pic.twitter.com/WPld3t0rJF</a></p>
&mdash; Cody Sanfilippo (@codysanfilippo) <a href="https://twitter.com/codysanfilippo/status/730406792140890117">May 11, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script></figure>

<figure>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p dir="ltr" lang="en">Who wore it best? The new Instagram looks a little Dunkin&#39; 😂😂 <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/instagramupdate?src=hash">#instagramupdate</a> <a href="https://t.co/g7Yhb3fbfr">pic.twitter.com/g7Yhb3fbfr</a></p>
&mdash; Ray Strazdas (@raystrazdas) <a href="https://twitter.com/raystrazdas/status/730503396562702337">May 11, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script></figure>

<p>But I digress. I don&rsquo;t know if I&rsquo;ll ever love this new Instagram icon&mdash;I didn&rsquo;t ever adore the old one, honestly&mdash;but I still think it&rsquo;s instructive insofar as it hints at key ways that mass-appeal consumer technology has changed through the smartphone era.</p>

<p>The new logo draws inspiration from current iconographic fashion trends as clearly as the old one did. Instagram debuted in 2010, and <span>turn-of-the-decade</span><span> </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skeuomorph">skeuomorphism</a> is impressed all over its original mark<span>. The pixel-tuned detail, the rainbow flourish, the leather that&rsquo;s as luxurious and approachable as the early iPhone itself: It exudes all the delighted optimism of early-2010s tech.</span></p>

<p>The new icon, meanwhile, is everything an icon is supposed to be in 2016: <span>flat, minimalist, </span><span>fluorescent, and confident. In probably the most important <em>branding </em>move of the whole redesign, Instagram brought its new gradient to its family of associated apps: Hyperlapse, Boomerang, and Layout. They look much more Instagram-adjacent now than the old ones did.</span></p>

<figure><img alt="" height="381" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/Screen_Shot_2016_05_11_at_6.49.12_PM/8046e165b.png" width="630" />
<figcaption class="caption">The old Instagram, Layout, Boomerang, and Hyperlapse icons above; the new ones below (Instagram)</figcaption>
</figure>

<p><span>But there&rsquo;s a broader change afoot than adherence to whatever the trend of the moment is. More than any other previous UI shift, the new icons divorce Instagram from its backward-looking past. </span></p>

<p><span>When it debuted, Instagram pitched itself as comfortable nostalgia. Into the anxious and frenetic early 2010s it rolled&mdash;that cheerful logo and the names of its filters recalling <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5jaiq_ZZ_eM">the Polaroid SX-70</a> and the other classic 1960s point-and-shoots. (The importance of the midcentury photography industry to the modern-day mobile business is hard to understate: One Apple designer or another is always praising the Leica.) It appealed not because it tried to guess at the future, but because it alluded to the warmth, neighborliness, and material permanence of an impossible past. Also, the filters made once-crappy smartphone photos look passable.</span></p>

<p>Now, Instagram doesn&rsquo;t need to appeal to any of that. It&rsquo;s just&hellip; Instagram. In my estimation, it&rsquo;s <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2015/07/i-like-instagram/398834/">the only social network that most people still genuinely like to use</a>. &nbsp;(And they don&rsquo;t need to use filters anymore.) The app&rsquo;s new interface, which was also redesigned, has dropped nearly every reference to its design antecedents. The interface is black and white, and the icons for each feature are the thin and simplified manifestations of their underlying metaphor. The &ldquo;discover&rdquo; feature tab, for instance, is barely a magnifying glass&mdash;it&rsquo;s a circle with a little line coming out of it.</p>

<p>So it is with the app&rsquo;s icon itself. Some have wondered why Instagram didn&rsquo;t retain more of the original &ldquo;camera&rdquo; logo in its minimalist update:</p>

<figure>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p dir="ltr" lang="en">The new icon feels great, I just wonder whether keeping slightly more of the original vibe might have been helpful&hellip; <a href="https://t.co/ckAkV3qNaQ">pic.twitter.com/ckAkV3qNaQ</a></p>
&mdash; Ian Storm Taylor (@ianstormtaylor) <a href="https://twitter.com/ianstormtaylor/status/730458234608181248">May 11, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script></figure>

<p>But the camera to which this new icon is alluding&mdash;it&rsquo;s barely even a camera. The designer Craig Mod <a href="http://www.newyorker.com/tech/elements/goodbye-cameras">has written about the &ldquo;networked lens,&rdquo;</a> his name for an image sensor hooked up to the Internet and a type of object that he believes will succeed and augment cameras. I&rsquo;ve written about how, until there is a major new change in function or form, <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2015/09/the-new-iphone-is-just-a-fancy-point-and-shoot/404626/">new iPhones and Androids will only remain compelling for their updated photographic specs</a>.</p>

<p>The new Instagram logo is two circles in a square, one of the most basic iconographic representations of a camera-like object that I can fathom. Two circles and a square represent a lens, a light source, and a web connection&mdash;except even the web connection is implicit. Once, Instagram attracted users by constantly citing precedent, by reminding users of their predecessors, by dunking every feature in a warm bowl of chunky nostalgia. Now, Instagram&rsquo;s just some lines on a screen. You know what to do with it.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><small><em>Updated on May 12 at 6:24 p.m. ET</em></small></p>

<p>The gun George Zimmerman used to kill Trayvon Martin and which he had hoped to sell Thursday now appears to be back on sale at another website&mdash;after it was pulled from the site where it was originally being auctioned.</p>

<p>The 9 mm Kel-Tec PF-9 pistol was initially listed for sale at <a href="http://www.gunbroker.com/Auction/ViewItem.aspx?Item=558112068">Gunbroker.com</a>, but the site later pulled the listing, <a href="http://www.gunbroker.com/User/Announce.aspx">saying</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Listings on the GunBroker.com web site are user-generated, exactly like social media posts. Mr. Zimmerman never contacted anyone at GunBroker.com prior to or after the listing was created and no one at GunBroker.com has any relationship with Zimmerman. Our <a href="http://www.gunbroker.com/User/SiteRules.aspx" target="_Blank">site rules</a> state that we reserve the right to reject listings at our sole discretion, and have done so with the Zimmerman listing.</p>

<p>We want no part in the listing on our web site or in any of the publicity it is receiving.</p>

<p></p>
</blockquote>

<p>The site now listing it is United Gun Group, <a href="http://www.unitedgungroup.com/auction/detail/auction/9/slug/george-zimmerman-s-gun-used-2-26-12">but that website appears to be down</a>. <a href="https://www.facebook.com/Unitedgungroup/?pnref=lhc">In a statement on Facebook</a>, that website said:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>United Gun Group offers a free platform for law-abiding citizens to buy, sell, trade and discuss firearms and related products. United Gun Group&rsquo;s stance is that as long as Mr. Zimmerman (or any other UGG member) is obeying the letter of the law, his personal firearm sale will be permitted on our network. &hellip; He appears to be following all applicable laws.</p>

<p></p>
</blockquote>

<p>Zimmerman, the neighborhood-watch volunteer, was acquitted of murder in the 2012 shooting death of Martin, a black 17-year-old, in Sanford, Florida. Here&rsquo;s an excerpt from the Gunbroker.com posting when it was still online:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Prospective bidders, I am honored and humbled to announce the sale of an American Firearm Icon. The firearm for sale is the firearm that was used to defend my life and end the brutal attack from Trayvon Martin on 2/26/2012. &hellip; Many have expressed interest in owning and displaying the firearm including The Smithsonian Museum in Washington D.C. This is a piece of American History.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>The gun, Zimmerman says, was recently returned to him by the U.S. Department of Justice. He said he hopes to get at least $5,000 for the weapon, and a portion of the proceeds &ldquo;<span>will be used to: fight BLM violence against Law Enforcement officers, ensure the demise of&rdquo; Angela Corey&rsquo;s career as a prosecutor, &ldquo;and Hillary Clinton&rsquo;s anti-firearm rhetoric.&rdquo; His posting ends with the words &ldquo;</span>Si Vis Pacem Para Bellum,&rdquo; a Latin phrase that means &ldquo;if you want peace, prepare for war.&rdquo;</p>

<p>BLM refers to the Black Lives Matter movement, which sprung up following several high-profile incidents in which white police officers killed unarmed black men. Corey is the Florida State Attorney who failed in her attempt to prosecute Zimmerman for killing Martin. She is up for re-election.</p>

<p>The Smithsonian, <a href="http://newsdesk.si.edu/releases/statement-smithsonian-george-zimmerman-s-firearm">in a statement</a>, denied it had expressed interest in the weapon.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>The Smithsonian has never expressed interest in collecting George Zimmerman&rsquo;s firearm. The Smithsonian has no plans to ever collect or display this object in any of its museums.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>The planned auction of the weapon prompted criticism Thursday. Indeed, Zimmerman <a href="http://www.fox35orlando.com/news/local-news/140127772-story">told WOFL-TV</a> in Orlando, Florida, he&rsquo;d received several death threats after putting the gun up for sale. &ldquo;What I&#39;ve decided to do is not cower,&rdquo; he said. I&rsquo;m &ldquo;a free American. I can do what I want with my possessions.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Martin was walking to his father&rsquo;s home in 2012 when he was shot and killed by Zimmerman inside a gated community. The neighborhood-watch volunteer said he felt threatened by the 17-year-old and successfully argued in court that his actions were protected by Florida&rsquo;s Stand Your Ground laws.</p>

<p>Since that time, Zimmerman has been charged with assault following complaints from two girlfriends, who subsequently declined to cooperate with police, leading to the charges being dropped.</p>

<p>The auction for his weapon was set to begin at 11 a.m. EDT Thursday and end 24 hours later.</p>

<p>Reacting to the planned sale, Daryl Parks, an attorney for Martin&rsquo;s family, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2016/05/12/trayvon-martin-family-attorney-george-zimmerman-gun-auction-insulting-and-disrespectful/?tid=sm_tw">told <em>The Washington Post</em></a>: &ldquo;It is insulting to this family that he would decided that he would sell the gun that he killed their child with. Think about what that means: This is a gun that took a child&rsquo;s life and now he wants to make money off of it.&rdquo;</p>

That&rsquo;s the shoes&rsquo; way of telling you&mdash;a little wobble, a little give&mdash;that all is well: that the shock of your footfall, <em>heelfloortoe</em>, <em>heelfloortoe</em>, is being absorbed. Dolly Singh, the CEO of the shoe design firm <a href="http://thesiscouture.com/">Thesis Couture</a>, is explaining this as I walk in a prototype version of footwear that has thus far been, due to limitations that are only partially technological in nature, pretty much impossible to imagine: shoes that are at once extremely high and relatively comfortable to wear. &ldquo;What you should be feeling is, hopefully, a lot less pinch in the front than you normally do in 4-inch heels,&rdquo; Singh tells me. &ldquo;Because of this arch-support area&rdquo;&mdash;she points toward the sole of the model I&rsquo;m wearing&mdash;&ldquo;it&rsquo;s supposed to push your weight back towards your heel.&rdquo;</p>

<p>You know what? It does. Or, at least, walking in a pair of Thesis stilettos&mdash;whose shanks, and heels, are constructed mostly of dense, slightly flexible polymer (&ldquo;ballistics-grade,&rdquo; Thesis&rsquo;s marketing literature points out)&mdash;minimized the reflex that walking in heels normally produces in me: the need to adjust my limbs and my overall self to compensate for my unnaturally raised foot. The shoes I&rsquo;m wearing, Singh told me, are only about 70 percent completed, design-wise; still, even at the prototype stage, you feel that cushion and that give and that reassuring little bounce. You feel the shock of your walk being eased. You definitely would not run in these shoes, in the manner of Carrie Bradshavian fantasy; you could, however, very reasonably walk in them. At least for, you know, a little while.</p>

<p>Singh, 37, is a former recruiter at SpaceX, Elon Musk&rsquo;s rocket engineering firm whose offices in Hawthorne, CA, consist largely of hangar and factory space. She spent much of her time on that job walking&mdash;&ldquo;about 3 to 4 miles a day,&rdquo; she recalls&mdash;on hard floors that were particularly ill-suited to the wearing of heels. She wore them anyway: Working in an industry dominated by men, she appreciated the few extra inches of height the shoes gave her. (And also: the sense of professionalism, and of femininity.) It didn&rsquo;t take much research to realize that many women, every day, live their own version of that compromise. So, when Singh left SpaceX, she recruited some of its employees&mdash;among them, yes, a rocket scientist and a former astronaut&mdash;to help solve a problem that is generally not treated as a problem at all so much as an unfortunate fact of ladylife: the insult and occasionally the injury that can come from the wearing of heels.</p>

<p></p>

<p></p>

<p class="dropcap">S</p>

<p>tripped of their symbolism, heels are, simply, shoes like any other: objects that help to separate the human foot, which is inconveniently soft, from the surface of the earth, which is inconveniently hard. And yet, of course, heels do&mdash;heels are&mdash;so much more than mere footwear. In their teetering heights, they make audacious assumptions about fashion and feminism and professionalism and sex and privilege and power and its opposite, and about the way all those things, in the early 21st century, chafe against each other. Heels at once lift women up and hold them&mdash;hold us&mdash;back. And, of course: We choose, day by day and week by week and <a href="http://www.lordandtaylor.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/en/lord-and-taylor/search/shoes/special-occasion-54154--1">Special Occasion</a> by <a href="http://www.aldoshoes.com/us/en_US/women/special-occasion/c/7129">Special Occasion</a>, to let them do it. Heels are both a claim of femininity and a test of it. They are the bindings of the willfully bound.</p>

<aside class="pullquote instapaper_ignore">&ldquo;I hate high heels, more than anything.&rdquo; - Cara Delevingne &nbsp;</aside>

<p>In that sense, while Thesis&rsquo;s comfortable heel represents a small feat, so to speak, it also represents a very large one: a counterargument to a longstanding assumption&mdash;rendered in fashion as well as in many other areas of the culture&mdash;that womanhood is defined, in part, by the ability to bear pain. Not just in the sense of &ldquo;suffering for beauty,&rdquo; as the saying goes, but in the deeper sense that the collision of those two things is integral to feminine experience. It&rsquo;s an assumption that helps to explain why stilettos have become such quintessential symbols of womanhood; it also helps to explain why they are, as those symbols, so deeply unsettling. Heels hurt. They slow their wearers down. They occasionally trip them up.</p>

<p>What Thesis&rsquo;s work suggests, though, is that the technology of the heel, the manufactured thing that takes its name from the natural one, could change the politics of the heel. The comfortable stiletto Thesis is promising is one that, simply because it hurts its wearers less, also demands less of them&mdash;and, by extension, of all of us.</p>

<p>Thesis is certainly not the first company to claim to have made a comfortable heel. What makes its approach unique, though, is that it isn&rsquo;t relying on low heel heights or thick heel widths or wide toe boxes or excessive interior padding&mdash;the stuff of dancing shoes and Naturalizers and their ilk&mdash;to improve its heels&rsquo; comfort levels. (&ldquo;Comfort shoe,&rdquo; indeed, is something of an epithet around Thesis&rsquo;s sleek L.A. office.) Instead, the company reconsidered the architectural framework of the shoe.</p>

<p>The people Singh recruited, from SpaceX and elsewhere, to advise Thesis in doing that work included Hans Koenigsmann, the (yes) rocket scientist. And Garrett Reisman, the (yes) former astronaut. And Matt Thomas, the former director of mechanical engineering at Oculus VR, the (now-Facebook-owned) virtual reality firm. And Andy Goldberg, an orthopedic surgeon. And Francis Bitonti, a designer&mdash;he created <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LazcMO028Ys">that iconic, 3-D-printed gown</a> for the burlesque star Dita Von Teese&mdash;who has become an expert at using algorithms to ensure garments&rsquo; fit. Singh also brought on Amanda Parkes, a fashion technologist, to ensure that the shoes the company created would be stylish as well as comfortable. Not running-shoe-comfortable, to be extra-clear, but for-a-high-heel-comfortable. &ldquo;What we&rsquo;re fundamentally trying to do,&rdquo; Singh explains, &ldquo;is make a stiletto that feels like a wedge.&rdquo;</p>

<figcaption class="caption">The inner workings of a Thesis stiletto (Thesis Couture)</figcaption>
</figure>

<p>To achieve that, the team first replaced the thin, metal spike that supports the typical heel with one made of that ballistics-grade polymer. Just as importantly, though, they played around with the shank of the shoe&mdash;the base of the sole, the structure that does the all-important work of arch support&mdash;in order to distribute the wearer&rsquo;s weight toward the heel and thus away from the ball of the foot, the source of so much orthopedic pain. Thesis&rsquo;s S-curved shanks lead to shoes that concentrate only about 50 percent of the wearer&rsquo;s weight there&mdash;an improvement from the current industry average of 80 percent.</p>

<p>The whole thing was much more complicated than Singh first anticipated. &ldquo;I came from rockets and VR,&rdquo; she notes. &ldquo;I thought that six months after I started this project, I&rsquo;d have the most amazing shoes that the planet has ever seen. And here I am, three years later&mdash;and I&rsquo;m <em>almost </em>finished.&rdquo;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s appropriate, though, that creating those shoes would transform from a &ldquo;project&rdquo; to a broader purpose: The appeal of heels&mdash;not just of sky-high stilettos, but also of their less audacious cousins&mdash;lies, most broadly, in their ability to function not just as footwear, but also as small, wearable symbols of mankind&rsquo;s tendency toward restless ambition. Heels have emerged from roughly the same impulse that led to cathedrals and skyscrapers and, yes, rockets: our desire to be taller, and grander, and generally more than we once were. &ldquo;You never find wonderful and great things on the ground, but instead placed on high, to fill others with wonder and reverence,&rdquo; Arcangela Tarabotti, a Venetian nun, <a href="https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/exhibitions/heels/">argued in the 17th century</a>. She was defending a very early version of the stiletto.</p>

<aside class="pullquote instapaper_ignore">&ldquo;The core of my work is dedicated not to pleasing women but to pleasing men.&rdquo; - Christian Louboutin</aside>

<p>So you can ask why heels, given all that they demand of their wearers, continue to be so popular&mdash;and, indeed, to be such easy tokens of femininity, used in everything from <a href="https://www.pinterest.com/pin/26880928999027492/?from_navigate=true">baked goods</a> to <a href="http://www.walmart.com/search/?query=scotch%20-%20Shoe%20Tape%20Dispenser%20with%203%2F4%20x%20350%20Roll%20Magic%20Tape%20-%20Honeysuckle">office products</a> to <a href="http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/01/15/463200139/taiwan-now-has-a-shiny-shoe-shaped-church">houses of worship</a>. You can point out all the compromises, large and small, that must be made when a person&mdash;usually, but not always, a female person&mdash;buys, and wears, and navigates the world upon, a pair of upthrust metal spikes. You can say (as Carrie Bradshaw, that character who derived so hefty a portion of her identity from her Manolo Blahniks, might have): <em>I couldn&rsquo;t help but wonder &hellip; What puts the &ldquo;I&rdquo; in &ldquo;high heels&rdquo;? </em></p>

<p>But to do all that, fashion being what it is, you also have to acknowledge all the things we women gain, or are told that we gain, from the wearing of heels, aesthetically and professionally and otherwise. Thesis Couture plans to include just 1,500 pairs of shoes&mdash;retail price: $925 each&mdash;in <a href="http://thesiscouture.com/wp-content/uploads/thesis_lookbook_ibook.pdf">its inaugural line</a>, coming out this fall. At a recent soft-launch event, in New York, Singh announced to the assembled crowd that they could add their names to the waiting list of people who have expressed advance interest in purchasing one of those pairs. The list, Singh told me, currently has more than 10,000 names.</p>

<p>So, yes: Let&rsquo;s talk about the &ldquo;I&rdquo; in &ldquo;high heels.&rdquo; But first let&rsquo;s talk about the we.</p>
